title: china truth coronavirus truth opinion
story: AN emotional Boris Johnson described how close he came to leaving this world, just as his new baby son was about to enter it.He was near tears as he told The Sun on Sunday’s David Wooding about the moment he realised he might die. “I’m a very lucky man,” he said.Our Prime Minister was indeed lucky.He was almost killed by a hideous bug we have learned to call coronavirus. Or Covid-.It should be known unflinchingly as “Chinese flu”.This virus was born in China, covered up by China, spread worldwide by China.In American bric-a-brac shops you will see signs saying: “You break it, you own it.” Covid- is owned by China.Chinese flu has paralysed the global economy, brought poverty to whole nations and increased the risk of death and disaster across the planet from other causes.The world is in lockdown, we are wearing face masks and latex gloves, avoiding friends and family, thanks to China.To avoid perhaps even more lethal pandemics, China must be brought to book.Beijing must allow us to find out precisely how this virus escaped, whether from a leaky laboratory or its hideous wet markets in Wuhan.The first indication of coronavirus was monitored as far back as November last year.China must explain why it silenced the doctor who raised the alarm and why it allowed millions of Chinese New Year revellers to travel far and wide long after learning the disease spread from human to human.Far from addressing these issues, China is doing everything possible to wriggle off the hook.Belligerent attacks, sanctioned by the Chinese Communist Party, are levelled against any country or inidual who dares ask questions.In an extraordinary outburst, China’s ambassador to Canberra threatened to beggar the Australian economy by cutting off trade in coal and wine.Similar warnings have been heard in Germany about car exports.Their crime  To call for a transparent investigation into the origins of this lethal pandemic.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal. Beijing’s aggression is working.The EU allegedly watered down criticism of the regime in a major report on Covid-, a claim it denies.Other world leaders, hopelessly addicted to Chinese money, are terried of offending this economic juggernaut.But the first duty of every leader is to protect their people.US President Donald Trump cites top-level intelligence that this bug began le in the Wuhan Institute of Virology.Nobody wants to hear inconvenient truth from Trump.So as a near-death survivor, it now falls to Boris Johnson, with his freshly enhanced international authority, to pick up the baton and lead the world in demanding answers.As he told ministers at his first Cabinet meeting, quoting his Roman hero Cicero: “The health of the people comes first.”He can start once this crisis has subsided by cancelling Britain’s reckless deal to give China’s state-backed Huawei a role in building our new G broadband network.The idea that heavily subsidised Huawei is independent of Beijing’s snooping rulers was always absurd.After the Covid meltdown, there is zero chance Tory MPs will vote this through Parliament.The world, brave Australia included, is rapidly reviewing its reliance on cheap Chinese supply lines.Beijing will scream blue murder, of course.But as the Chinese like to say, every crisis presents an opportunity.Boris should make a virtue of necessity and turn this “new normal” attitude to China into official Government policy.The World Health Organisation, heavily reliant on Chinese cash and goodwill, is also in the dock.This UN body is supposed to protect the world from perils such as coronavirus.Instead, its pro-China leaders turned a blind eye until way too late.China must not be allowed to bully or buy its way out of this mess — or to “save face” at the expense of countless millions of lives, now or in the future.China must be held to account.Having left his death bed full of “terrible buoyancy”, Boris Johnson is just the man to do it.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for title: coronavirus masks being stockpiled for public ben wallace admits
story: MINISTERS are stockpiling masks for Brits to wear as Government prepares to consider changing official health advice, it was confirmed today.Defence Secretary Ben Wallace said the UK was trying to get as many masks as possible and have been saving them up for weeks.Later this week an official decision on facemasks is expected to be taken by the UK Government, and Brits are set to be told to wear them in enclosed spaces or on public transport.Scotland has already told the public to start wearing them, as they can have an impact on stopping sick people with no symptoms from passing it on.Mr Wallace said today: Its not the amazing thingyou wear a mask that no ones going to get it but there is obviously this issue about human nature and interactionsyou go on public transport and wear a mask will you feel able to go back to work.At the same time, to anticipate should dferent rules be made around masks were trying to source as many masks as possible as we speak and have been for the last few weeks.The news comes as:It comes after Micheal Gove revealed that they were looking into building up a supply last week.He said a domestic effort has been launched to slow the spread of coronavirus after he was challenged by Labours Rachel Reeves to build a stockpile for the public.Such masks will be used to limit the droplets that each of us might be responsible for, he said.The Sun previously revealed that scientic experts had changed their advice to Government, but they have been mulling over whether to make a formal change to the advice.Ministers are concerned that any decision to tell Brits to cover up may stop people from socially distancing, as they feel more confident.And they are keen that no surgical masks are taken away from NHS staff who need them on the frontline.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Instead, Brits are set to be told to wear face coverings instead - anything from a home-made cloth mask to covering up with a scarf.Boris Johnson admitted last week that they would be useful in helping the country get back to work.He said: I do think face coverings will be useful, both for epidemiological reasons, but also for giving people confidence that they can go back to work.And you will hear more about that next week.It follows weeks of debate and speculation other whether members of the public will be asked to wear face coverings.Boris is expected to outline the lockdown release plan later this week, with a possible timetable of how the country can get moving again.However, experts have stressed that the R rate of transmission must get to the lowest possible number first.The PM said today: Thank you for all youve been doing to stop the spread of the coronavirus.Thanks to all of you I believe we are making progress.But we will only be able to move onto the second phase of this conflict when our five tests have been met.We must be confident that any adjustments to the current measures will not risk a second peak of infections that overwhelms the NHS.Then will be the time to move onto the second phase. The worst thing we can do now is ease up too soon and allow a second peak of the coronavirus.Any number above one will mean the virus starts to spread again and cases can soar.Schools are expected to open again from June, starting with primary schools and then years  and taking exams next year.Yesterday Grant Shapps laid out some of the plans for transport to restart again.Officials are looking at one-way systems in train stations and hand sanitser on trains as part of moves to open up the system.But train bosses are concerned they wont be able to put on enough services, and will be only able to run to  per cent of their total capacityeveryone has to stay two metres apart.Mr Wallace also revealed this morning that the two-metre guidelines may be relaxed in workplacesthey are able to use other ways of keeping themselves safe.He suggested that PPE and shields like for supermarket workers could be used to keep people safely apart.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: haunted louisiana mansion given away free
story: But its listing has prompted people to share spooky memories of the property, including one ex-resident who creepily claims her great-grannys spirit still stirs the pot in the kitchen.The title: china us russia snub global vaccine summit
story: Three of the worlds leading superpowers chose not to dial in to pledge to work together to help develop testing, vaccines and treatments for the virus.The UK co-hosted today’s virtual summit Innovations to find a vaccine.We have committed up to £ million for the global response to coronavirus, including our pledge of £ million for the vital research and development of vaccines, treatments title: coronavirus lockdown uk two tests end completed
story: BRITS were tonight given hope of an end to the lockdown after it emerged two of the governments five key tests to lt it have apparently been passed.The government has set five tests that need to be met before it will start easing the lockdown that has been in place since March .Addressing that at tonights daily press conference, Englands deputy chief medical officer Jonathan Van-Tam said: The first test is around NHS capacity and were in a good position on that one.Earlier today it was revealed the London NHS Nightingale Hospital - which was designed to care for , patients at a time - will be shut next week. title: hidden cellar home plymouth
story: Jake Brown, from Plymouth, Devon, noticed one wall had dferent textures and decided to inspect further.He drilled a hole in the wall big enough to get his head through it to check the area.When he took a look, Jake discovered there was a huge cellar underneath his home, so he opened the wall to investigate.Inside the tunnel he discovered items including paint cans, a -year-old newspaper as well as bottles from the early s.Jake said: I recently moved into a Georgian property in Emma Place.While having a lazy coffee standing outside the basement front door of the property I noticed a patch in the wall of a texture dferent to the rest.I also noted that the patch was the same distance from the coal cellar already exposed, currently used for storage.Curiosity and a little boredom got the better of me, after which I grabbed a drill and began working pilot viewing holes into the wall.Once I had made two holes, one for viewing, one for a torch, I peered through into the dark dusty expanse and realised that it was another cavern of sorts.After realising what was beneath his house, Jake opened the wall up so that he could climb down and walk inside.He added: I proceeded to hammer out a larger opening through which I could get a better idea of the space, andI should carry on making mess.Upon creating a large enough hole to fit through, I shone a torch into the dark, revealing the larger than expected space before me.The cavern had a lot of builders waste from another era, so I climbed inside to explore and take a closer look.He soon realised the area was bigger than he had expected.Jake added: I measured the rough area of the space and observed its structural integrity.I was pleased to note that the stone arched ceiling was in great condition and the expanse measured a healthy m deep, m high, and m wide.In the area, Jake found piles of building waste and other rubbish, so started digging through it all for clues.He said: Upon inspection it confirmed that the space had been covered up for many years.It had been used as an easy space, to hide the waste from renovating the propertys roof, guttering, doors, and windows many years ago before being covered up.As I moved deeper into the cavern I began to search for evidence that would tie it to a grouping of years so as I could more accurately determine how long it had been covered up.In the dark I collected bottles, paint cans, and my golden find was the remains of a newspaper, though was more comparable to mushy silt.After preparing the newspaper in a bath filled with water, Jake was finally able to open a few pages in search of a date.He added: I laid the items I had collected out in the clear light to identy their age.The paint cans were extremely degraded but had enough detail to show that the labelling was of a s s era style.The bottles, after a quick wipe, were etched with detailing common also of the early s.The biggest reveal was the newspaper, it almost disintegrated upon human touch, so a CSI style method was used to carefully peel back the congealed layers.I proceeded to run a warm bath and soaked the congealed brown mess in the solution for a period of time, after which tweezers and vibration were used to slowly work shards of the paper free while submerged.After as many fragments of the paper had been recovered as possible, I photographed while still submerged and removed what was salvageable for drying.I scanned through the jumbled pieces looking for dates or usable information to determine the era.There were little hints the style of writing, no colour, picture style, currency and then finally a date!What was barely readable was the year , this along with the other pieces of evidence fitted, meaning the cellar had been blocked up for over  years.Armed with evidence, Jake contacted a historian friend, Richard Fisher, to ask for his input.Jake added: That evening I excitedly reached out to a local historian, Mr. Richard Fisher. I described the findings and asked his guidance.Richard said: The whole area before then was a large hill called Windridge Hill for obvious reasons.This was quarried away to almost high tide level, then the houses when built into the hole with cellars, undercrofts etc.However these early cellars, this one looks to be for coal, were built out not only underneath the pavement but out into the road.The load on the roads would have been much lighter than now.I have seen these places turned into wine cellars, a place to grow mushrooms, andbig enough, a grotto type bathing area...

title: cyclists coronavirus lockdown social distancing
story: CYCLISTS are being targeted by coronavirus vigilantes during the lockdown, with some suffering verbal abuse and others being injured, it has been reported.The UKs two biggest cyclist organisations have warned of a culture of hostility against those who take to the road to exercise.Cyclists in Somerset have been targeted by drawing pins placed on roads, while others have been injured by motorists speeding or carrying out close passes.Some signs warning cyclists against entering some villages have been spotted in several counties, including Cambridgeshire, Cheshire and Powys.One resident even daubed the sentence stay home cyclists covidiot on a road in the Chew Valley, Somerset, The Times reports.However, it is believed that many cyclists are being targeted because of concerns they are breaching social distancing rules - by riding in groups or far from their homes.Cycling UK and British Cycling have written a letter to The Times, saying they are concerned about an increasing number of reports of cyclists and cycling clubs being targeted and vilied while out riding.The alleged abuse led Sharrow Cycling Club, the oldest cycling group in Sheffield, to cancel organised rides, although some members still exercise alone - which has created furious reactions among local residents.Pete Collins, the club chairman, said: Many people are using the lockdown as an excuse to air their long-held grievances against cyclists, which in our case we believe to be unwarranted and unfair.Riders have cut their distances in half or more, are staying relatively local and are complying entirely with government guidelines on social distancing.Cycling is permitted as a form exercise during the coronavirus lockdown, with no fixed limits on how far or for how long people can ride.Cycling UK advises those who want to go out on their bikes to use common sense when planning your route - but still doing enough exercise to keep in good shape physically and mentally.British Cycling and Cycling UK said many people are also using their bikes to deliver prescriptions, raise money or feed families during the lockdown.They added: There is no trusted evidence to suggest that cyclists are any more likely to spread the disease than runners and walkers,they follow the social distancing requirements.However, the groups have asked the public to show tolerance, warmth and care towards those who get out on their bikes during this crisis.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - title: joe wicks lockdown jamie oliver
story: RIGHT then, Joe Wicks. He’s just Jamie Oliver with a skipping rope, I assumed, before this wretched lockdown business began.A character we’ve all seen in our local park, with a pair of boxing gloves and a stopwatch, charging financial managers £ a haemorrhoid to do some sit-ups over by the ornamental lake.One of Britain’s ever-growing army of personal trainers who,he wasn’t bouncing around on YouTube every morning, would be clogging up Love Island or Ex On The Beach.That’s what I thought, anyway.Then the coronavirus hit, the local swimming pool shut, the man became a phenomenon and before I could come to my senses, Joe and his infernal timing device were beeping away in my living room, every morning, as I joined in his PE lesson. Inevitably, it didn’t last.First, Joe’s routine did me what I can only describe as “a mischief”.Then, one morning, aged , I caught sight of myself, in a picture frame, doing his “reverse frog shuffle” and thought: “Stuff this for type two diabetes. I’m out.”I’d got no closer to understanding Joe’s astonishing popularity, though, which is truly global.Over , people log in just to stare at his fairly spartan living room, every Monday to Friday.Hundreds of thousands more appear when Joe starts his  minutes of physical jerks.So, in an attempt to unlock the greatest mystery of the outbreak, I kept watching Joe and swtly came to the conclusion success was not linked to his presenting skills.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Because, for a host, he has a strangely distracted and chaotic air about him, with sessions regularly being interrupted by technical issues, forgetfulness and tiny daughter Indie, who charged in, dressed as Zog the dragon, on Friday.He’s not the greatest multitasker either, as Joe often demonstrates with the geography quiz he’s introduced to jolly things along.“What is the capital city of Moscow. . .   No. I mean Russia.”He also has to believe me when I tell him he’s not one of le’s natural comedians.“What’s the capital of Cuba  Fray Bentos. Nah, only joking.”The jokes need to go the same way as the viewers’ poems, in honour of Joe, which he was actually reading out loud, until modesty finally prevailed.Much safer ground is the “spot the dference” competition, which borders on insulting, when he’s merely placed his wall atlas upside down or swapped his electric guitar for a ukulele, but does hint at the drive, ambition and ego behind the man.One day he replaced the atlas with a picture of himself, the next with a picture of his “other house” in Los Angeles and suddenly the penny dropped.Joe’s loaded and his head is not just on its way to Hollywood, it’s already there, making movies and doing squat thrusts with Gwyneth and Brad.The weird thing is, in other presenters, soap actors or comedians, I’d roll my eyes at the folly.With Joe Wicks, I don’t. ’Cos I can’t help it, I quite like him.Part of that may be linked to his no-frills background and a level of personal generosity that’s way beyond most of us .But I like to think it’s got more to do with the fact that, at a time when other cynical, doom-mongering TV hosts are desperately trying to read the public mood, reinvent themselves and force their agenda on viewers, Joe Wicks is just doing what he’s always done. Sit-ups.He may not be Emily Maitlis , but he’s the irrepressible and lucky optimist telling us to get off our fat a***s when we need to hear it most.He’s temporarily indisposed at the moment, of course.A gammy arm means we Rosie is leading the workouts.But I was firmly of the opinion nothing and no one could ever stand in the way of world domination, until I tuned into Sunday night’s Diva On Lockdown and there was Gemma Collins trying to contort her mighty bulk into one of Joe’s squats while she bellowed: “I wonder how Joe Wicks would feelhe knew the GC was doing his workout ”Beaten, I’d imagine.He must never know.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.And her face is glued to the back of her head.So there will be hell to payit comes unstuck on The Real Marigold Hotel, where the only other one of the eight celebs who’s appeared looking as unearthly as Britt is former Dragons’ Den star Duncan Bannatyne, whose hair is now a “vibrant and colourful” shade of roast papaya orange. And will remain that way, until the monsoon breaks.It’s probably safe to say neither of them will be hanging around that long, though, or “retiring to India” any time soon.This is the fourth series of the BBC show and not one of the famous pensioners has given the place a second look yet.They have, however, all come home alive.So I wish the Beeb would count its lucky stars, cut the pretence, make Duncan pay for everyone’s holiday and let us all enjoy their discomfort, which is considerable and very entertaining.During the first episode: John “Nasty Nick” Altman proved as supple as Tower Bridge at his first ever yoga lesson.Paul Chuckle remained confined to barracks with the trots.Henry “Blowers” Blofeld rejected insect repellent on the grounds that: “Mosquitoes get p***edthey bite me.”And actress Susie Blake certainly didn’t hold back when the local foot doctor told her: “You have some unwanted growths.”“Yes, I have haemorrhoids.”Susie, too much inflammation.Jamie Redknapp: “We always used to turn up late but somehow we’d make it in time.Martin Keown: “Vieira was the best I ever played with. But Henry was a great player, so don’t make me choose between them.”Paul Merson: “The secret to working hard is to work hard.”ON one particularly fraught episode of her Channel  show, last week, Steph McGovern was forced to let a wasp out of her living room window, live on air.Probably halving her audience in the process.A day later it was announced the show itself was being released back into the wild, or as they put it “taking a break”.Credit for this development was being given to Steph’s long-suffering neighbours, who’d objected to the disruption the production had caused and may yet get a Bafta fellowship for their intervention.Truth be told, though, Steph’s “power hour of positivity” was more likely killed by worthiness, lack of content, technical issues and the host herself, who’s a rotten interviewer, kills every good joke stone dead, has the same set response to everythingand a terrible habit of asking exactly the wrong question.“Martin , what are you doing with all that toilet paper ” “Errr . . . ”There’s talk of a brave new dawn, in a shiny Leeds studio, later this year and when I last checked, author Marian Keyes was giving some pointed advice on how to become a good novelist: “Your first efforts will be woefully appalling. It’s like anything in le you want to be good at. Keep showing up.”Steph. Don’t.MORE now from Russell Grant’s “uncannily accurate”  predictions in December’s Mirror.“Scorpio — travel will be a great source of joy for you in April.”Yeah, April. How’d that work out for you Netflix thriller series Fauda. Channel ’s SAS: Who Dares Wins . Episode two of BBC’s Jewel Of Arabia .BBC repeating Bob Monkhouse: The Last Stand.And BBC Breakfast discovering that not only is he a war hero and charity giant, he’s a former Blankety Blank contestant as well.Cometh the hour, cometh Colonel Tom.Craig: “Arm.”Bradley Walsh: “What vowel precedes the name of more than ten dferent Apple products ”Becky: “C.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which word used to describe horses of a reddish brown colour is also a type of window ”Paul: “Velux.”RE: The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “The name of what flightless bird is slang for someone who refuses to face facts ”Becky: “Kiwi.”You mock, but I shouted: “Diane Abbott.”Table, restaurant, postcode, country, Commonwealth of Nations and beyond that, his own gravitational field.Dumbest question was obviously: “Would you like dessert ”CHANNEL ’s When Will Lockdown End  The highlights.Professor Hugh Montgomery: “I don’t know.”Professor Graham Medley: “Anyone who tells you they know is lying.”Professor Peter Horby: “We just don’t know.”So in conclusion, try asking Russell Grant.RANDOM irritations: Have I Got News For You echoing to nothing but the sound of its own self-satisfied laughter.ITV numbskulls destroying Van Der Valk’s famous theme tune.Toxic hypocrite Frankie Boyle biting the Press hand that’s fed him far too well, by the looks of things.BBC’s Panorama failing to reveal every single interviewee on Has The Government Failed The NHS  was a left-wing activist.And ITV’s Joel Dommett making we Hannah the co-host of his Home Alone show.Which is a bit like Linda McCartney sharing lead vocals with Ringo. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: RADICAL measures to prevent the spread of coronavirus in workplaces will be in place for up to a year, The Sun has been told.Screens between desks, staff sitting back-to-back and a ban on hot desking and sharing of equipment are among moves employers must introduce when lockdown is lted.The new measures — proposed in draft documents on ato workplaces — also require staggered sht times to avoid crowding on public transport.Handwashing kit must be at entry and exit points, with regular cleaning of worktops. necessary and be time-limited.Employees will even be told not to share stationary such as pens.The message to employers is to allow their staff to work from homethey’re not needed in the workplace.It means home-working will likely become the default for millions of Brits for the foreseeable future.But employers will have to monitor the well-being of staff working from home by keeping in touch to ask about their welfare, physical health and personal security.The Government has told industry groups the new measures will have to be in place for between six and  months.They were told there will seasonal.An industry source said: “If it survives the winter, these measures will have to be in place longer.”But one positive industry bosses are drawing from the new measures is the impact it will have on dampening traditional flu.The draft papers cover seven dferent settings: offices, hotel and restaurants, shops, factories, outdoor workplaces and those who work in vehicles and other people’s homes.Staggered sht times, less sharing of equipment and continued maximisation of home working are among a number of ideas listed as part of a draft government strategy to help businesses prepare for ato work.Increased hygiene procedures and the installation of protective screens are also included in the plan.Efforts to avoid employees working face-to-face will see them working side by side or story: A GOVERNMENT fund of £million has been set up to help zoos and aquariums care for animals in the pandemic.The attractions have lost visitor income but still face costs of feeding, heating and security of their animals.The Department for Environment, Food  Rural Affairsalso plans to continue working with some of the largest zoos to discuss longer term concerns.Animal Welfare minister Lord Goldsmith said: “Zoos are facing real pressure and we have made support available, including business rates relief and the business interruption loan scheme.“This new Zoo Support Fund is designed to help those that need support to maintain the welfare of the animals.”Inidual grants of up to £, will be available for English sites covered by the Zoo Licensing Act.Steve Barclay, Chief Secretary to the Treasury, said: “Zoos don’t just provide a family day out but are vital for education, species protection and conservation.”Dr Madelon Willemsen, chief of the British and Irish Association of Zoos and Aquariums , said zoos and aquariums had gone to extraordinary s to cope with the pandemic while looking after animals despite the lack of income.“We are pleased to have worked with Defra in shaping this much needed crisis support for zoos and aquariums.“We continue to work to ensure those most in need have access to this and other forms of support.”Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the sun concerts key workers register
story: OUR army of key workers is heroically keeping the country running during this crisis.They have put their lives on the line to make sure the nation is safe. Now we will show our gratitude.The Sun has teamed up with Virgin Radio to host the Big Thank You Tour, a three-night UK arena extravaganza that will feature top music acts.And we are giving away , tickets to key workers — from NHS staff to carers, teachers, transport staff and shop assistants — who will be our guests of honour.The first concert will be held at Wembley SSE Arena on October .It will also incorporate our annual Who Cares Wins Awards — paying tribute to NHS staff, ­volunteers and charities who have touched, and saved, lives.Nominations will open next week.The tour will continue to Manchester Arena on October  and then Glasgow’s SSE Hydro on November .The Sun editor-in-chief Victoria Newton said: “The Sun’s Who Cares Wins Awards recognise the hard work, dedication and sheer brilliance of our NHS staff, from porters to nurses to surgeons.“This year, with so many heroic stories em­erging from the Covid- emergency, the Awards will be bigger than ever, and on a bigger stage than ever. And what better way to kick off the Big Thank You Tour, giving thousands of key workers a party to remember.”Mike Cass, from Virgin Radio, added: “Key workers have done the most amazing job of keeping Britain going.”Registrations for the tour open today at www.thesun thankyou. Fill in your details to be in with a chance of you, and your plus one, attending a concert.A ticket ballot will be used to randomly select the gig-goers. All attendees must be aged  or over. Under-s must be accompanied by an adult.If government guidance means the tour cannot go ahead this autumn, gigs will be rescheduled for when it is safe to do so.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: healthy over 70s to be freed from strict lockdown
story: OVER-s should be able to self-select whether they are vulnerable or not once the lockdown is eased, ministers have said.It follows criticism that using age-based criteria to lt restrictions would lead to social unrest.About . million clinically vulnerable people have been told they must stay in lockdown for at least  weeks, with some ministers saying they might need to remain at home until there is a vaccine, which could take a year or more.They include people aged  or older regardless of medical conditions and those under  with an underlying health condition.As the government reviews its lockdown policy, British Medical Association and the Royal College of GPs said a wholesale lockdown of the elderly was discriminatory and unacceptable.Former minister Baroness Ros Altmann, , said Britain faces social unrestthe over-s are forced to live in a longer lockdown than younger generations.The Conservative peer said many older people would risk going to prison rather than being forced to isolate at home.Charity Director at Age UK Caroline Abrahams also spoke out against blanket policies based on age.Comedian Sir Michael Palin, , agreed in a separate interview that age restrictions would be very dficult and very wrong and very unfair.Amid the criticism, a minister close to the discussions concerning elderly and vulnerable people told thethe over-s will self-select whether they are vulnerable or not.They told the newspaper: The all over-s grouping is going to morph. There is a big dference between the . million shielded people, known as extremely critically vulnerable, who have been sent a letter advising them to shield for  weeks, vulnerable people with pre-existing health conditions of any age, and healthy over-s.This needs to be made clearer – you cant just have a blanket over-s group. Thats unsustainable. Its not a static group.The minister added: There arent enough supermarket delivery slots to cater for that amount of people.What we are going to see is more self-selection and personal responsibility.People will self-select whether they are vulnerable or not. The over-s are a very sensible group – by and large, they knowthey should be staying indoors or not.Meanwhile Tory Sir Graham Brady said on Monday night: We have today the most healthiest, active elderly generation of all time and it would be tragicGovernment threatened this by trying to extend a so-called lockdown for those judged to be most at risk based on age.Why dont we just give them the best information and advice and let them limit their risk themselves In the original Government guidance, anyone over , regardless of their state of health, was advised to be particularly stringent in following social distancing measures.But on May , that was withdrawn and replaced with new advice which listed all over-s as clinically vulnerable.Amid confusion over the guidelines, Health Secretary Matt Hancock tweeted: The clinically vulnerable, who are advised to stay in lockdown for  weeks, emphatically DO NOT include all over-s.The Department of Health and Social Care confirmed over s are not included in the most at risk group , who have been told to isolate for  weeks.On Monday, the Prime Ministers official spokesman said: Over-s are classed as being in the clinically vulnerable group – they are not necessarily in the clinically extremely vulnerable group, which are those people who are shielding.Therefore the advice to them is to take particular care to minimise contact with others outside their household.Asked whether the over-s would have dferent rules from other sections of the population, the spokesman added: We know that, as you get older, there is a higher risk of coronavirus having a more serious impact. Complications and deaths are more common in the elderly, even those without pre-existing conditions.But as we look forward it is perfectly reasonable that we will look at how guidance will apply for dferent age bands, and we will continue to be guided by the science.The UK coronavirus death toll hit , on Monday as another  patients died in the lowest rise in more than a month.The last time the UK recorded such a low  hour fatality rate was almost five weeks ago on March  when  deaths were reported.However there is often a drop in Mondays figures due to a lag in reporting over the weekend with Tuesdays number likely to be higher.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ten ways honour ve day 75 years katherine jenkins vera lynn
story: To keep social distancing, there will be no audience in the venue during the classical singer’s half-hour rendition of wartime favourites, including a virtual duet of We’ll Meet Again with Dame Vera Lynn, .And Katherine’s solo concert, which will be broadcast on YouTube, won’t be the only celebration on Friday.The Sun is calling on YOU to lt the country’s spirits by putting on the best stay-at-home parties.It’s your chance to have fun while paying tribute to -year-old fund-raising hero Colonel Tom Moore and all the other World War Two veterans who fought for our freedom. Before lockdown, the early May Bank Holiday was moved to Friday to give millions of us a three-day break.And we are not going to let Covid- stop us from marking this special day – just like millions of Brits did on May , , when Nazi Germany’s surrender ended war in Europe.From wonderful wartime songs to fabulous food and games, our guide will help you put on a party.We’ve also included a TV guide and the lyrics to Dame Vera’s anthem so you can join in with a national singalong after the Queen addresses the nation.It’s going to be a day to remember for all the family.So will you please say helloWe’ll meet againWe’ll meet againKeep smiling throughSo will you please say helloWe’ll meet againSINGER Katherine Jenkins took part in celebrations that were staged  and  years after VE Day – and she is proud to perform again during these dficult times.She said: “While we may not be able to celebrate this year as we once did, it’s only right that we don’t allow the th anniversary of this historic day to be overshadowed.“I wanted to do something to help bring the nation and the world together in commemoration and celebration at this dficult time.“I’m excited that we can still come together, albeit virtually, for a tribute of wartime songs and musical memories from London’s most iconic concert venue.“The Royal Albert Hall will be seen like never before – empty, isolated and yet still breathtakingly magnicent.”Katherine will sing wartime favourites The White Clfs Of Dover and We’ll Meet Again – referenced by the Queen in her coronavirus address when she urged the nation to “remain united and resolute”.Dame Vera, now  years old, says: “I hope this special duet lts the spirits of our VE Day veterans and all those separated from loved ones at this time.”The performance starts at pm on Friday.To find out how to watch, see royalalberthall ve.THERE were many tunes that kept the nation going during the dark days of war.Here’s our top ten. You can listen to them by searching for each one on YouTube.PAUSE to raise a glass at pm – that’s when Dame Joan Collins is going to lead the nation’s toast from the balcony of her London home.She will pay tribute to women in the war during her public address which is expected to be covered by TV news networks.The -year-old actress, who is also appearing on Lorraine on ITV earlier in the morning, said: “We must never forget the selflessness of all those who sacriced so much to keep us free during the Second World War.”Here is The Sun’s very own toast to the nation . . .To the heroes of the Second World War, we salute you.To the heroes of the war against Covid-, we thank you.THERE are plenty of traditional games that the whole family can play at your VE Day party. Here are some of the most enjoyable.MUSICAL BUMPS: The children dance around in the centre of the room. When the music stops, they must sit on the floor as quickly as possible. The last one to sit down is eliminated.CHARADES: Split into two teams and take it in turns to act out your favourite films, songs, TV shows or sports.But try not to make them too dficult!MUSICAL STATUES: While music plays everyone moves around, either dancing, hopping or skipping, then freezes when it stops.The first one to move is eliminated.The music is re-started and the process repeated until a winner is crowned.HIDE AND SEEK: Probably the most-loved children’s game of all time – and you don’t need any equipment to play it.One player closes their eyes and counts up to  while the other players hide.The seeker then tries to find the hiders.The first one found is the next seeker and the last is the winner of the round.Test your knowledge of VE Day with our fun quiz:HANG out the bunting – a few rows of colourful triangular flags add a dash of fun to your decorations. Get the whole family involved.Encourage your children to cut out triangles from anything they can find around the house – scrap paper, empty cereal boxes, string, ribbon or even sweet wrappers. They can colour the shapes in with felt-tip pens.You could even dig out old Christmas decorations and adapt them.The BBC’s Make A Dference campaign has some great ideas for making bunting.There is even a template you can download.To find out more, see bbc makeadference.Lance Bombardier Ben Parkinson, pictured, who lost both legs and suffered brain damage when his armoured Land Rover hit a mine in Afghanistan in , is backing the BBC initiative.He says: “Join me and make great British bunting.”TRY making some wartime grub. With rationing and food shortages, the nation had to make the best of what was available in .Lord Woolton Pie was a favourite, containing potatoes or parsnips, carrots, caullower, swede and sometimes turnips, all topped with potato pastry and grated cheese. Also popular was Homity Pie – a pastry case containing potatoes, onions and leeks topped with cheese.Meat dishes included dripping sandwiches with beef fat, pork faggots with onion gravy and mash, liver casserole and corned beef hash.While butter and many other kitchen basics were rationed during World War Two, beer never was as it was considered essential for the nation’s morale.That’s probably why our troops showed so much bottle!YOU can’t go wrong with this delicious cake recipe. There are just a few easy steps and it takes only  minutes to bake.Heat your oven to C fan C gas . Butter two cm sandwich tins and line with non-stick baking paper.In a large bowl, beat g caster sugar, g softened butter,  beaten eggs, g self-raising flour,  tsp baking powder and  tbsp milk together until you have a smooth, soft batter.Divide the mixture between the tins and smooth the surface with the back of a spoon. Bake for  mins until golden brown.Take out of the oven and leave to cool completely.To make the filling, beat the g softened butter until smooth and creamy then beat in g sted icing sugar.Spread the buttercream over the bottom of one of the sponges.Top it with g strawberry jam and sandwich the second sponge on top.Dust with icing sugar before serving.It will keep for two days, but you’ll want to eat it straight away.IT’S a right royal day of telly with The Queen leading the way. Here’s the pick of the best viewing.am, BBC:The Nation Remembers. A two-minute silence to mark the th anniversary of the end of the conflict in Europe. This national moment of remembrance will pay tribute to heroes of the past and present..pm-.pm, BBC: The Announcement Of Victory. Military music, personal testimony and readings feature in this tribute to the Second World War generation. It includes Sir Winston Churchill’s historic victory speech in which he addressed the nation to announce the end of the war in Europe, which he made from  Downing Street on May , .pm-pm, BBC: The One Show. Alex Jones and guests celebrate the th anniversary of VE Day.pm-pm, Channel : The Lost Films. Eyewitness accounts and cine films of ordinary people charting that extraordinary day  years ago when the nation took to the streets in spontaneous celebrations.pm-.pm, ITV: Captain Tom’s War: Memories of the brutal Burma campaign that has become known as the forgotten war.pm-.pm, BBC:The People’s Celebration. Recollections and music of the Second World War, featuring Katherine Jenkins, Adrian Lester, Anton du Beke, Beverley Knight, Shane Richie and actress Emma Barton.At pm on the programme, Her Majesty the Queen addresses the nation followed by a national singalong when everyone is invited to join in with We’ll Meet Again as a way of saying thank you to the brave veterans who fought in World War Two.pm-pm, Discovery Channel: Tony Robinson’s VE Day Minute By Minute. Documentary painting an evocative picture of a nation celebrating the declaration of peace..pm-pm, BBC: Remembering Victory. Famous names share memories of VE Day. Narrated by Julie Walters and featuring David Attenborough. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: family find spiders tesco bananas
story: Melanie Price saw  of them swarm from their egg sacs as she unpacked a Tesco shop.The -year-old rushed outside with husband Daniel, , and kids Oliver, three, and Emily,  months.Supermarket chiefs told the family they must have their home fumigated as they are highly likely to be poisonous Brazilian wandering spiders.The South American critters’ venom is the deadliest in the world — and its bite can also cause an erection lasting up to four hours.Chef Daniel bravely bagged up the p Costa Rican bananas and baby spiders, whose leg span can grow to ins, and ed them to their local store in Wadebridge, Cornwall.Their house has now been sealed off for two weeks by pest controllers.Melanie said: “They take two hours to kill a human. title: bumble couple lockdown together meeting once
story: A COUPLE have been living together in lockdown after deciding to move in together on their second date.Emma Johnson was at Nic Powell’s house on March  when Boris Johnson announced restrictions.The events manager said: “We just thought everything is going really well, why not just lockdown together “So we’re sort of still on our second date six weeks in!”Emma, , and Nic, , met on dating app Bumble.The couple have been splitting their time between her home in Warwick and his  miles away in Solihull.Emma’s French bulldog Herbie is also with them.Project manager Nic said: “Everyone thought we were being crazy, but it’s been fantastic so far.”“By the time it all goes back to normal,we haven’t killed each other, we might just stick together.”Emma added: “We can’t wait to see what happens.“There are a lot of things we want to do after lockdown, a holiday is top of the list but obviously we need to be careful.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: live frogs turtles china wet market
story: Officials in Beijing shut down wet markets after early cases of the coronavirus were linked to the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market in Wuhan.Wet markets were able to resume trading as of mid-April.The Chinese government banned the breeding, trading and selling of wild animals in February, but has yet to publish a full list of what is considered wild.The law has yet to become permanent as officials are looking for what the public thinks is wild animal or livestock.So far  animals are considered exemptions from the ban including cattle, pigs, poultry and camels.There are further  species that would fall under the special tag and also be exempt and those include: reindeer, alpaca, pheasants, ostriches and foxes.The full list isnt expected to be finalised until mid-May and until then it appears openly selling wild animals can resume.It is understood most animals like frogs, turtles and scorpions are on a list of banned animals - and there is still a demand from buyers.One city in China has already banned eating cats and dogs in a historic new law.Shenzhen, a city of around  million people, will end the trade on pet meat.Lawmakers in Shenzhen have passed China’s first ruling to ban the sale of meat from cats and dogs - which came into effect on May .It comes after a video taken at the Tomohon Traditional Market in North Sulawesi, Indonesia, has emerged showing butchers carving up animals in the open and customers free to roam through the crowds.The coronavirus is believed to have emerged from such a market in the city of Wuhan late last year.Wet markets traditionally sell fresh produce and live animals, such as fish and exotic animals, which are butchered in the open air.They tend to be popular with shoppers who believe the items on sale are cheaper and fresher than in supermarkets.But theyre poorly regulated.The suspected source of the killer bug, the Huanan Seafood Market, has not reopened.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - title: british airways planes sabotaged
story: Five tons of fire retardant covered the jets in a hangar at Heathrow on Sunday.The Boeing  and  planes will be out of service for months after their fuselages were damaged.And the final clean-up bill is expected to cost the airline hundreds of thousands of pounds.The finger of blame was originally pointed at disgruntled BA staff facing either redundancy or agreeing to contracts with less pay.At least  engineers, some of whom were at the scene, are among the , staff getting the boot.But British Airways has insisted a technical issue was to blame.An insider told The Sun: “There’s a lot of p***ed off people at BA at the moment and suddenly two of their jets have been ruined.“Suppressant foam is not easy to clear up. This mess is going to take weeks to sort out. It’s ruined the tools, aircraft, everything in sight.“BA staff claimed sabotage. title: boris must ease lockdown soon
story: Boris Johnson cannot be sure the NHS would not be swamped by a second wave of infections.He has, though, taken out comprehensive insurance: The expansion of health service capacity was so huge that it can now afford to shut the new ,-bed Nightingale Hospital in London and place it on standby.The PM’s “unlockdown” decision was urgent even before the grim news of two million new benefit claims. Our formerly thriving economy is on its knees, losing billions a day. Huge numbers of jobs have been lost, many permanently.Matt Hancock’s new “track and trace” app may prove a great addition to the armoury against Covid- and we urge every Sun reader to download and use it when available. But we cannot wait for such tactics to bear fruit in the statistics.We are past the peak. Deaths are on their way down. The NHS was nowhere near being overwhelmed and that looks increasingly unlikely.The Government must not be swayed by the lockdown’s continued public support. That will evaporate once the long-term economic consequences sink in.We strongly disagree, though, with those who never thought it necessary — and make spurious comparisons of our death totals against countries of very dferent sizes and population densities.And we know what a tough call this is. But easing us imminently back to work and school, using social distancing and masks, is the right one. Yes, an NHS unable to cope would be a catastrophe.An even greater one is a prolonged lockdown . . . and a nation engulfed by bankruptcies, unemployment and poverty.WHAT a golden excuse the lockdown has been for every bossy busybody to exercise their authoritarian urges.Even so, we never imagined anyone would be mean-spirited enough to moan about the weekly clap for our ­carers — let alone for local councils to act on such petty grievances.One, however, has issued a warning to tone down the applause and Vera Lynn songs after a single complaint. Another has told a barman his sponsored singalong after the pm clap is too noisy.Do officials simply lack the backbone to tell these whingers to lump it Or do they actively enjoy sealing off ­avenues of pleasure EVEN in these grim times one announcement yesterday was too much to bear:“We have tried to make Love Island this summer, but it’s just not possible.”Our hearts are broken.What will we talk about now When will the Queen again address her disheartened nation Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: members house lords paid login coronavirus
story: MEMBERS of the House of Lords are being paid £ to simply turn on their computer while the chamber is shut due to coronavirus.The  peers usually receive an attendance allowance of £ per day.They now get half of that for taking part in virtual proceedings — costing taxpayers up to £, per day.They qualy for a daily allowance because they are not given a salary.There is no minimum time or requirement on participation.It means peers can log-on to a debate and not even have to speak to receive cash.The House of Lords Commission recommended new rules to prevent abuse of the system during the coronavirus pandemic.It suggested Lords will need to show active participation in proceedings either virtually or in person - for example through a Select Committee meeting or speaking in a debate.But they will not be able to receive the money for simply following proceedings online or in the chamber.Lords Speaker Lord Fowler, who chairs the commission, said: We are proposing to replace the current allowance with a lower working allowance that reflects the fact that Members are not incurring the same overhead costs while carrying out their work from home.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. We also know as we see that care home transmission continues to be a very signicant challenge.All things considered, decisions are yet to be formally taken, it is almost very likely that on Thursday I will be asking you to stick with lockdown a bit longer. It comes ahead of a major announcement about the governmentaposs plan for easing lockdown.  On Sunday the Prime Minister is expected to explain  his roadmap for easing restrictions  in an address to the nation. But he is not expected to relax the lockdown immediately - as the timing of his speech makes clear. Under current plans, heaposll give his address three days after the lockdown has to be reviewed by law on May .That suggests Mr Johnson will extend the lockdown for another three weeks this Thursday, perhaps with some minor changes, until the end of May. Only then, after the lockdown has been officially extended, will he begin to officially discuss how it will be lted in future. Downing Street officials are understood to have deliberately pencilled in Thursday and Sunday as two distinct events in the diary.

And there are still doubts about whether itaposll work. So what does it all mean for you  Hereaposs an explanation. What is apostest, track and traceapos  Itaposs the government plan that will guide the second phase of Britainaposs coronavirus outbreak.Once lockdown starts to ease, itaposs vital to keep a close eye on how quickly Covid- is spreading to make sure there wonapost be another peak.That means testing everyone who might have Covid-, tracking all their movements, and tracing everyone they might have been close to in.The programme will be done using an NHS appplus , human contact tracers, , in call centres and , in the field. Why is contact tracing so important   The strategy must be in place before Boris Johnsonaposs plan to ease the UK lockdown can happen. To stop a second terrying peak of the virus, health officials must know exactly where it is in the community and how fast it is spreading. With proper contact tracing, anyone who is infectious can quickly be isolated from their friends, family and co-workers. That will mean the aposRapos number - the number of people infected by each Covid- carrier - will stay low. If R is below , the virus spreads slowly in the community. If it is above , it spreads exponentially and can end up doubling every few days. If apostrack and traceapos works, it means society can slowly open up again, with people ing to work and having limited contact with friends in a new normal, while not being overwhelmed by disease.How will the app work  Using Bluetooth Low Energy signals - designed not to drain your battery too fast - the app will log each time it comes into close range of other devices also running the app. It will then keep an anonymous record of all these logs securely on a useraposs phone. If someone develops symptoms of Covid-, they can use the app to inform the NHS. That will then trigger an anonymous alert to any other app users the infected person came into contact with by analysing the collected logs. The app will then advise what action to take, including telling people to self-isolatenecessary. They can use the app to order a home testing kit to be delivered to where they live. The group of a dozen experts were gathered by Sir David King, a former government chief scientic adviser.He assembled the rival boffins to look at how the UK is handling coronavirus over fears that ministeraposs claim to be following the scientic advice, but have failed to share recent the information behind those decisions with the public.Sir Davidaposs group, which held its meeting online, said it has been organised “in response to concerns over the lack of transparency” from SAGE after it emerged that Boris Johnsonaposs top aide Dominic Cummings and another Tory aide had attended a meeting in March. It came as Downing Street published the names of the more than  scientists who sit on SAGE. The list of names showed that around half of the experts come from universities and another half is made up of Government chief scientic advisers, public health officials or NHS senior staff.One Google executive, Demis Hassabis, attended in a personal capacity as a data scientist, the company confirmed after people raised questions over the inclusion of a figure from a private company.Mr Cummings is not listed as a member, despite reports he attended meetings and contributed to discussions. Two members of the group did not give permission for their names to be published. The minutes of the groupaposs meetings have not been released, and neither has the most recent advice which No  claims underpins their decisions. The new Independent SAGE group warned that lting lockdown at dferent times across the country could lead to anger and resentment.Officials are considering how coronavirus restrictions could be lted, and later this week Boris Johnson is expected to set out a road map out of the lockdown.They also warned that Britainaposs strategy could be overly reliant on finding a vaccine. Professor Gabriel Scally, who is President of Epidemiology  Public Health Section of the Royal Society of Medicine, told the committee that we needed to prepare for a vaccine that could be several years away. Professor Scally, who advises the Irish government, added: We can hope for the best, but we must plan for the worst-case scenario  and find ways to keep going on that basis and ways to keep our economy and society operational. Professor Susan Michie warned that lting certain restrictions for dferent sections of the economy, areas or age groups risked undermining the collective solidarity that has been so important for trust, for adherence, for helping each other. She added thatspecic groups such as the over-s are asked to stay in lockdown while others are not, the message would have to be much more nuanced. The tough measures will be imposed in a bid to stop a deadly second wave. Boris Johnson is expected to relax some rules and firms could reduce distancing at workthey get PPE. But TUC boss Frances O’Grady branded the move an “open goal” for rogue bosses to cut corners. While there may light at the end of the tunnel for cooped up Brits, experts warn strict measures will be brought in to avoid a ­deadly second wave of coronavirus. While some restrictions look likely to be eased in the coming weeks, regions could face local lockdownsthere are signs of another outbreak there. As the death rate rose by  to , – the smallest rise since last month – leaked guidance showed the Government is considering relaxing the ­two-metre distance rule for some businesses as they slowly start to get the economy moving. The documents, covering seven key sectors of the economy, recommend companies adopt extra measures such as physical screenskeeping a gap between workers is impossible. But union chiefs warned they could not back the proposals as they fear rogue bosses would not implement the rules properly – putting staff and the wider community at risk. Boris Johnson, seen today arriving at No with a coffee in hand, is expected to reveal the first ­relaxation of some lockdown rules on Sunday, days after the ­three-week review is completed on Thursday. The Government hopes the “test, track and trace” approach – eventually used alongside the new NHS app being trialled on the Isle of Wight – will allow it to take a localised approach.  Soa city such as Manchester, for example, became a virus hotspot after the ­lockdown had been eased, testing could begin on a large scale and contact-tracers deployed. A source said: “If you saw a worrying increases of ­transmission in regions, then you would want to move quickly to try to stop those.” Schools and non-essential shops could be closed, to help drive back down the crucial R transmission rate between people, while the rest of the country continued as normal. Wearing face masks is likely to be the new normal for shoppers still fearing a second wave of the virus. As part of the national easing of restrictions, the PM is expected to say primary schools could reopen for some pupils – most likely Year Six – as early as June .  But other tough ­restrictions will remain until there is a vaccine, with cinemas, pubs and ­theatres likely to stay closed for months. And those who can work from home are expected to be asked to continue. Department of Business officials are drawing up guidance to get people back to work in the coming weeks. Recommendations could include staggering sht times to ease the rush hour, avoiding hot-desking or sharing pens, closing lts and canteens. Bosses are currently advised to keep workers two metres apart wherever possible.  But the guidance states: “It will not always be possible to keep a distance of m. In these circumstances both employers and employees must do everything they can to reduce risk.” Cabinet minister Ben Wallace signalled some firms will be allowed to adopt other measures, even halving the distance to one metreworkers are given screens and protective kit. He said: “You could wear PPE, that could be a possibility, or indeed you could find other ways of doing it, shielding for example.” But unions slammed the guidance – which only asks firms to “consider” the moves – insisting bosses should be forced to adopt them.  TUC general secretary Frances O’Grady said: “Throughout this crisis the TUC has sought to engage constructively with ministers. But we cannot support the Government’s back-to-work plans as they stand. They are an open goal for rogue employers, who will cut corners and put their workers, and the wider community, at risk. “We want new binding rules for employers to publish their risk ­assessment. We want clear ­guidance to set out the minimum standards that employers must meet in order to protect public safety. And we want ministers to outline a new tough approach to enforcement.  Unless the Government ­signicantly strengthens its plans, safe working will not be ­guaranteed. The current proposals fail to provide clear direction to those employers who want to act responsibly.” Labour leader Keir Starmer has called on Mr Johnson to form a “national consensus” on the next phase of the coronavirus response as ministers work on the plans to ease the lockdown. He backed the ­extension of ­measures ahead of talks with the PM this week. Mr Johnson yesterday co-hosted a virtual conference of world leaders aiming to raise more than £.billion to develop a vaccine. But China and the US failed to turn up. No played down their absence insisting the summit was “only the start” of the pledging process.

story: NewsBored man discovers -year-old tunnel under his house while doing DIY in lockdownJake Brown found that one of the walls in his recently bought Plymouth home had dferent textures, before drilling down and finding a secret passage containing items from "another era"ShareCommentsByAdam AspinallRyan MerrieldJohn Bett:,  MAY NewsJake Brown was doing some work at his newly bought home when he found a secret passage " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA bored man who decided to do some DIY during lockdown discovered a secret -year-old tunnel underneath his house. Jake Brown was doing some work at his newly bought home when he realised that one wall had dferent textures. He inspected further and made an opening big enough to get his head through to take another look. To his shock, Jake discovered there was a huge area underneath his home in Plymouth, Devon, so he opened it up to investigate.Inside the tunnel he discovered items including paint cans and an old newspaper that proved the tunnel had been blocked up for more than  years, the Plymouth Herald reports.And he found evidence on bottles that the tunnel itself was from the early s. Jake said: “While having a lazy coffee standing outside the basement front door of the property I noticed a patch in the wall of a texture dferent to the rest. “I also noted that the patch was the same distance from the coal cellar already exposed, currently used for storage. “Curiosity and a little boredom got the better of me, after which I grabbed a drill and began working pilot viewing holes into the wall.  “Once I had made two holes, one for viewing, one for a torch, I peered through into the dark dusty expanse and realised that it was another cavern of sorts. After realising what was beneath his house, Jake opened the wall up so that he could climb down and walk inside. He added: I proceeded to hammer out a larger opening through which I could get a better idea of the space, andI should carry on making mess. “Upon creating a large enough hole to fit through, I shone a torch into the dark, revealing the larger than expected space before me. “The cavern had a lot of builders waste from another era, so I climbed inside to explore and take a closer look.  He soon realised the area was bigger than he had expected. Jake added: I measured the rough area of the space and observed its structural integrity. “I was pleased to note that the stone arched ceiling was in great condition and the expanse measured a healthy m deep, m high, and m wide. In the area, Jake found piles of building waste and other rubbish, so started digging through it all for clues. “Upon inspection it confirmed that the space had been covered up for many years.  “It had been used as an easy space, to hide the waste from renovating the property’s roof, guttering, doors, and windows many years ago before being covered up. “As I moved deeper into the cavern I began to search for evidence that would tie it to a grouping of years so as I could more accurately determine how long it had been covered up. “In the dark I collected bottles, paint cans, and my golden find was the remains of a newspaper, though was more comparable to mushy silt. After an arduous process of preparing the newspaper in a bath filled with water, Jake was finally able to open a few pages in search of a date. He added: “I laid the items I had collected out in the clear light to identy their age. “The paint cans were extremely degraded but had enough detail to show that the labelling was of a s s era style. “The bottles, after a quick wipe, were etched with detailing common also of the early s. “The biggest reveal was the newspaper, it almost disintegrated upon human touch, so a CSI style method was used to carefully peel back the congealed layers. “I proceeded to run a warm bath and soaked the congealed brown mess in the solution for a period of time, after which tweezers and vibration were used to slowly work shards of the paper free while submerged. “After as many fragments of the paper had been recovered as possible, I photographed while still submerged and removed what was salvageable for drying. “I scanned through the jumbled pieces looking for dates or usable information to determine the era. “There were little hints the style of writing, no colour, picture style, currency and then finally a date! “What was barely readable was the year , this along with the other pieces of evidence fitted, meaning the cellar had been blocked up for over  years. Armed with evidence, Jake contacted a historian friend, Richard Fisher, to ask for his input. Jake added: That evening I excitedly reached out to a local historian, Mr. Richard Fisher. I described the findings and asked his guidance.” Richard said: “The whole area before then was a large hill called aposWindridge Hillapos for obvious reasons. “This was quarried away to almost high tide level, then the houses when built into the hole with cellars, undercrofts etc.

This week, we asked Lynda and Jovan to be the first participants in a ground-breaking new project, Britain Connects – launched today by the Daily Mirror and . A year after we pioneered Britain Talks, which was aimed at getting the UK chatting across the Brexit ide, this is a new virtual version. This time we want to build on the new connections forming across Britain as we face the Covid- pandemic together. “Jovan is a lovely young man,” Lynda says, after the pair connect via Zoom, chatting for almost two hours. “It felt like we really did know each other straight away. I’d love to go out for a cup of tea with him when the lockdown is over. On paper, we seem dferent - we voted dferently in the election - but we share a lot of the same values.” Jovan agrees. “I would have never spoken to someone like Lynda in my normal le,” he says. “We just wouldn’t have met and politically we seem very dferent, but we had a lot in common..”  The Daily Mirror asked the pair to meet up for a virtual chat, as our country reaches a moment of peak isolation. Lynda, new to modern tech ‘whatnot’, chats from the living room of her flat in Batley Carr. Jovan, a digital native, is in his childhood bedroom in the Midlands with his guitar. Our readers up and down the country are overcoming isolation by connecting with people they wouldnapost usually meet for an online chat. Do you want to join them YES IaposM IN Lynda thinks the Prime Minister is doing a reasonable job, “the best of a bad lot” who will “get Brexit done”. Jovan is a Labour supporter who “did everything in my power to stop Boris being elected” and voted Remain. Born  years apart, Lynda’s biggest fear is of catching Covid-, while Jovan worries far more about what comes next for his already-struggling generation.But, as they chat, they discover they both come from NHS families. Jovan’s grandmother came to Britain from Ghana in the s to work in the health service as a midwe. His mum is now a matron at Birmingham City Hospital. “She’s at the hospital right now,” Jovan says, “on the frontline. We’re very proud of her.” Lynda’s dad was a pharmacist from Wallasey, as well as a navigator in the RAF during the war. And it even turns out Lynda, a former theatre and paediatric nurse, was a matron herself too. “I was nursing for  years,” she says. “Twice my letime,” Jovan laughs. “I retired two years ago otherwise I would have been on the frontline myself,” Lynda says. “You know what it’s like, mum’s in there all hours,” Jovan says. “On her day off yesterday she was called out and was there for the whole day.” While Lynda voted Conservative and Jovan is an active member of the Labour Party, both are upset by the lack of PPE for frontline workers. Lynda previously ran a care home and is especially worried for carers. Jovan worries for his mum and her colleagues.  “My mum said one of her staff members had to go in with a motorbike crash helmet because they didn’t have enough PPE,” Jovan says. Lynda nods. “I was screaming at the TV news. I could see what was going to happen and I couldn’t do anything about it.” Jovan says: “I hope this is a  moment where people say there’s been a particular way of doing things that hasn’t really worked… so we need to fund things, we need to treat people with more dignity and respect.” Lynda nods: “Exactly.” For Britain Connects, the Mirror and Express are also partnering with the Behavioural Insights Team. “The coronavirus crisis has created a shared experience without precedent for all of us,” Antonio da Silva says. “This unique situation also means that while we adjust to the pandemic there is an opportunity to connect and bring people closer together as never before. “We will draw on evidence from behavioural science to help make that contact as fruitful as possible and in the process learn more about bridging ides between people.” It turns out Jovan and Lynda share many interests. Born in Liverpool, Lynda talks about nights spent as a student nurse at the famous Cavern Club, watching the Beatles. Jovan plays bass in the Themselves Houseband, as part of a collective that organises arts events in London. “I went to school with Paul McCartney and John Lennon, that’s my only claim to fame…” Lynda says. “I think that’s cooler than anything I could ever say!” Jovan laughs. Jovan is a keen cyclist and is amazed when Lynda produces her exercise bike. “It keeps my legs exercising while I watch the telly,” she says. “I do  pedals a few times a day. That’s more cycling than you today Jovan…” While Lynda is living off hot cross buns and prosecco brought round by a neighbour’s son, Jovan is desperately missing trips to the pub. They say they are both “living like students”, staying up late in front of the TV. They both wish they could get to the hairdresser, and Lynda teases Jovan for hiding his lockdown locks under a back-to-front baseball cap.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMy aunt was among the NHS workers recruited from the Caribbean in the Sixties. When Britain desperately needed nurses she answered the call. She would serve this country’s Health Service for  years among a tranche of foreign key workers proving their worth long before the coronavirus. After a stroke in , my mum was cared for at the Homerton Hospital in East London. The staff there were diligent, compassionate and caring to a fault.When I clapped on that first Thursday I fought back the tears that actually shocked me by welling up as I reflected on what the NHS means to me. It matters. Every doctor, nurse or ancillary worker could be my aunt for whom the patients were a priority and the job meant everything.I’ve been clapping ever since.Now though, I’d rather see action than clap again. I’d rather our everyday heroes were paid proper money than lip service, while those same doctors and nurses are doing their jobs without the equipment they need.With a teacher we, a headteacher sister and a brother-in-law who works in the emergency services, I see first hand the dedication of our key workers. One friend of mine sleeps at the hospital where he works to reduce the coronavirus risk to his family. Yet clapping now has become the thing some people do on auto-pilot. The exhausted Facebook mum shamed by her neighbours for sleeping through it last week is an example of the social pressure that has overtaken a well-meaning act of appreciation. How does abandoning social distancing and massing on Waterloo Bridge at pm on a Thursday night help our NHS When the clapping is led by politicians and critics who supported doctors and nurses being denied pay rises then you know you’d rather find another way.
