title: royal-mail-stop-saturday-letter-deliveries-due-coronavirus-pandemic
story: It said it will continue to provide its letter delivery service from Monday to Friday as normal and said customers ldquoshould continue to post both letters and parcels as usual on Saturday.Royal Mail will continue to collect all mail from businesses, post offices and post boxes, it said.When will Saturday deliveries temporarily stop The will be halted from this weekend .What have Royal Mail said Shane OrsquoRiordain, managing director of marketing, regulation and corporate affairs at Royal Mail, said: ldquoOur postmen and postwomen are working very hard across the UK in challenging conditions.ldquoAs we said at the start of the coronavirus crisis, there will be some disruption to services.ldquoWe understand the importance of the postal service in keeping the UK connected at this time.ldquoWe have also listened to our hard-working colleagues who have asked us to ease the additional burden on thempossible. As a result, we are making some temporary changes to postal services.Royal Mail said it has been in dialogue with the Government and regulator Ofcom throughout the crisis and will keep the temporary change to postal arrangements under review.Reaction to the moveThe decision was criticised by the Communication Workersrsquo Union , which represents postal workers.A CWU spokesman said: ldquoWe will be seeking urgent discussions with the Government on this issue.ldquoThe reduction of the Universal Service Obligation was a key factor in our live national strike ballot.ldquoThe last thing we want to do is call strike action at this point but we will not sit back and see our membersrsquo jobs put at threat and the service to the public worsened.Last month the union called for householdsrsquo deliveries to be cut to three days a week due to coronavirus.

title: teachers-well-placed-assess-students-grades
story: The Scottish Qualications Authorityhas revealed how it aims to determine the  exam results for students due to sit them, following the suspension of normal examinations due to Covid-.And Lesley Brown, the councilrsquos chief operating officer for education, said schools were prepared to provide the evidence needed and review the results using their professional judgement.She said: ldquoWe know that the closure of schools and the cancellation of exams has caused anxiety and uncertainty for our pupils and their families. Irsquom pleased that the SQA has now confirmed its approach, and I am especially pleased to see recognition that teachers and schools are best-placed to provide a judgement on pupilsrsquo achievements.ldquoOur schools regularly monitor and track pupilsrsquo progress throughout the academic year as part of our approaches to ensuring high-quality learning, teaching and assessment. Teachersrsquo professional judgement is at the heart of our approach in Scotland and our teachers are very well placed to provide the information required by SQA.ldquoWe are working with our headteachers and school teams to make sure that our approach across East Lothian is consistent, rigorous and accurately reflects pupilsrsquo achievements. Our teachers will estimate grades using all evidence available to them, with support from their subject faculties, wider school teams and from our central education team.The SQA says its approach to awarding grades is based on safe and secure certication following public health advice and maintaining the integrity and credibility of the qualications system.Schools and colleges will be asked to provide the SQA with estimates on pupilsrsquo achievements, grades, bands and rank based on their performance so far in subject activities.This will provide an overall judgement from those the SQA describes as ldquobest placed to do so, with submissions due by May .The SQA will then check and validate the estimates it receives and look at prior assessments undertaken by pupilsthey are available ndash for example, Higher results for an Advanced Higher pupil.The schoolsrsquo previous history in estimating attainment will be considered and SQA will hold Awarding Meetings with its subject experts.Results will be delivered to learners by August  and students are encouraged to register for MySQA to receive their results by text and or email.The appeals process will remain free for schools and colleges so they can advocate on their pupilsrsquo behalfthe results do not reflect the candidatersquos achievements.The SQA has an exams QA for parents and pupils on its website, www.sqa.org.uk

title: pubs-may-limit-drinkers-three-pints-lockdown-lifted
story: Heres what you need to know.What social distancing rules could pubs face When pubs reopen for business, patrons could be limited to three drinks each before being asked to head home, in order to free up space for others to visit, a government advisor has suggested.The strict rules would also include maintaining a social distance of two metres while inside, with landlords able to issue fines to those who flout the rules.The terms are outlined in a plan by economist and government advisor, Professor Eyal Winter, who said social distancing is the key to coming out of lockdown. He also argued that the public need to know what the government has planned in terms of a lockdown exit strategy.Speaking to , he said: ldquoPeople are starving for pubs. They are an important part of British culture.ldquoOne of the most important things is to have a programme, to say, lsquoIn two weeks we will do such and such.rsquoldquoYou need to make the rules crystal clear, and to explain to the public the rationale behind each one of them.When are pubs likely to reopen Professor Winter estimated that it will take ldquoa lot of time to move back to how le was in January , but was certain that the country ldquowill get there.The Mail Online has reported that a possible exit plan could see the UK come out of lockdown in phases. The public would allegedly be allowed back into outdoor spaces first, with pubs being the last to open, as the lockdown was lted.Cabinet Office minister, Michael Gove, confirmed that areas of hospitality will be among the last to see restrictions lted.When asked whether pubs would open ldquobefore winter, Mr Gove told Sky News: ldquoThe other inference that I draw from your question, which is that areas of hospitality will be among the last to exit the lockdown - yes, that is true.What about cinemas and theatres Professor Winter has also been advising ministers on how to go about lting lockdown, and said cinemas and theatres could also reopen, but must have half empty auditoriums.Every other seat would have to be unoccupied, but he said venues could make up for the loss of money by raising ticket prices.

title: neighbours-join-forces-ensure-memorable-80th-birthday
story: James Walker, known as Jim, lives on St Margarets Road with we Valerie and celebrated his big day on Monday.Initial plans were for his daughter Morag to travel from Ireland, where she currently stays with her partner and family, and his two sons Alastair and Graeme to visit from Staffordshire and Edinburgh respectively.However, the coronavirus lockdown changed this, and meant that his family were not able to be by his side.Morag contacted Jim and Valrsquos lsquolockdown street linkrsquo for the area ndash put in place by the townrsquos resilience team ndash to askanyone could make a cake for her dadrsquos birthday.Morag said: ldquoI knew the street link lady is an active member of the community so would knowanyone was able to help.The plan snowballed from a kind neighbour making a chocolate cake to other neighbours gathering in front of Jim and Valeriersquos house to sing a socially distanced lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo.When he heard his doorbell ring, Jim was amazed to find the chocolate cake at the front door.Neighbours from nearby Marmion Road and St Margarets Road struck up a chorus of lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo, while Jim waved from the doorstep.He then walked to the pavement to thank everyone.ldquoItrsquos a lovely day for us to eat cake and have a cup of tea in the garden, said we Valerie.Morag said: ldquoMy dad was a bit taken aback but really appreciated the surprise. Hersquos looking forward to trying the cake.Jim was born in Gullane on April ,  but has spent most of his le in North Berwick, attending the local schools.He spent all of his career as a quantity surveyor and is a member of the local bowling club.He met Valerie, who is from Prestonpans, at the Pavilion dances in North Berwick, where the Scottish Seabird Centre now stands.The pair married  years ago.Morag said: ldquoWe were going to come over with the whole family and help him celebrate. title: bridges-project-continues-vital-work-lockdown
story: Regular face-to-face sessions and group activities at the Bridges Project on Bogpark Road have been replaced with phone calls, text messages, video calls and digital work as the lockdown becomes challenging for some.Despite the dficult times as a result of the pandemic, staff have discovered ldquopositive elements of lsquoremotersquo working with young people in East Lothian and Midlothian. They have now been working from home for more than a month and have continued to support vulnerable and disadvantaged young people with ious issues which has brought about some ldquounexpected outcomes.Lynne Anderson, transitions development worker, has noticed that she is able to use her time more wisely by phoning her clients instead of driving up to an hour each way to visit them at their homes.She said: ldquoWe can use this situation to learn how things work dferently. There are opportunities to continue doing some of the activities we are doing remotely when weto normal.She is one of several staff members who have had to change the way they give support over the past weeks but it still focuses on many of the same issues. They provide help with filling out job and college applications, and provide young people with emotional support and tutoring. The response has also generally been very positive, with staff members reporting engagement levels of up to  per cent from their clients.Natasha McInninie, transitions service co-ordinator, said: ldquoI am surprised by how resilient young people are. I thought we would lose a lot of young people through this situation. However, it has actually made them engage more.Emma Scarclfe, acting chief executive, is also very pleased by how both Bridges Project staff and the young people they work with have responded to the current crisis.She said: ldquoBridges Project has adapted quickly to the unexpected situation around Covid-. Engagement continues to be extremely high and the commitment and dedication from staff to change their working practices so quickly to suit each inidual young person has been a complete triumph. Wersquore all very proud of the way young people have adapted and how resilient they are.However, there are also issues which have become ldquomagnied during the lockdown, for example, people who have dficult relationships with their family members struggle with being ldquolocked up together over such a long period. Others are affected by less income and need help with accessing food parcels, Universal Credit and other types of financial support.Many young people also need help to deal with the impact the Covid- crisis is having on their mental health. This is particularly the case for those who were already struggling with social anxiety or social isolation prior to the lockdown.Lynne said: ldquoIn the beginning, the young people thought it was fantastic. Now the reality of the lockdown is settling in and it is starting to become challenging.This trend has also been observed by personal development worker, Chris Nicol, who said: ldquoThe young people were dealing with it well during the first few weeks but have seen a downturn in their mood over the last two weeks. This is due to a combination of boredom and too much time to think but also not seeing their friends. They have realised how important those social anchors really are.He highlighted the importance of keeping young peoplersquos motivation and confidence up during these challenging times.He explained: ldquoI remind them that they need to focus on the fact that this will last for a relatively short period of their lives and things will go back to normal.Thank you for reading this story. title: goblin-ha-inspires-author-release-first-fantasy-novel
story: Goblin Hall, described as ldquoa humour-laced fantasy adventure for all the family, marks the latest chapter in the ied career of Peter Kerr.Widely known for his Snowball Oranges and Bob Burns Investigates series, he has turned his hand to another genre, with a nod towards The Goblin Harsquo, a reputedly haunted chamber that lies beneath the ruins of Yester Castle, near Gford.He said: ldquoI actually wrote the story, I think, about  years ago.ldquoIt was when my first book, Snowball Oranges, was just coming out, after waiting about  years to get published.ldquoI had an agent in London at the time and she said the way I write is very visual and I should have a go at writing a film script.ldquoI had never even read one but took her at her word and looked at the layout and general routine for laying down film scripts.ldquoAs for the The Goblin Harsquo, I had been to the old castle, with one of my pals who lived in Gford, when we were both about  way back in the s.ldquoThe place itself was not much to see, except peeking into the underground chamber, which inspired me.ldquoIt was bloody frightening and a very spooky place ndash it stuck in my mind.It was only two years ago, when transferring stories to a new computer, that Peter revisited his original film script and set about creating the novel.The legend of the Goblin Harsquo states that Sir Hugo de Gfard, known as the Wizard of Yester, made a pact with the devil to raise a magical army, who he used to carry out his will.Peterrsquos new tale, which is available from Amazon, features an evil sorcerer called Zorn, who has lured two young children into his subterranean lair as bait to ensnare his arch rival, a wizard called Mungo.It is up to the lovable but dippy old wizard to help free the youngsters from Zornrsquos clutches.The author, of Haddingtonrsquos Chalybeate, said feedback about the story was ldquoquite encouraging.That came despite the -year-old making an interesting revelation to the Courier. He said: ldquoI honestly donrsquot think I have ever read a fantasy novel!ldquoThat same literary agent, when she was trying to get a publisher for Snowball Oranges, told me detective novels were always popular.ldquoIrsquove never read one of those either and she said, lsquowell,you write one it will be original, evenit is rubbishrsquo.ldquoThat was the same attitude I took towards writing the fantasy novel.ldquoThe reaction so far has been quite encouraging.Peter was in popular s jazz band the Clyde Valley Stompers, who charted with Peter and The Wolf and were supported by The Beatles before the Fab Four made it big.Later, Peter produced more than  albums ndash including the Royal Scots Dragoon Guardsrsquo international chart-topper Amazing Grace ndash the biggest-selling instrumental of all time with  million sales.Thank you for reading this story. title: nisa-store-steps-donates-1-300-charities-vulnerable
story: Pinkie Farm Convenience Store, one of Nisarsquos independent outlets, has donated essentials to the vulnerable and families in the area who are struggling with financial hardship.Support from the store ndash led by managing director Dan Brown ndash has included a pound donation to East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes, pound to Resilient Musselburgh and a further pound to Pennypit Community Development Trust.East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes provide fresh produce boxes containing all the ingredients needed to prepare a full roast dinner to struggling families.The charityrsquos founder, Jane Russell, said the donation would provide  local families with their dinner boxes.She commented: ldquoI set up the project in December  to give out free fresh chicken dinner boxes to people financially struggling in East Lothian.ldquoThe idea was to create a box of fresh produce so they had everything to cook a Sunday roast chicken dinner, and so the families could all sit together and enjoy a healthy meal.ldquoWe have helped over  families so far. The reason I set it up was because I myself have been in that position and, with three kids, financially struggling is so hard, decidingyou can afford food or gas.ldquoI wanted to make our project easy for people to ask for help without any forms to fill in or feel embarrassed.ldquoThe feedback and the support from the local community to help us is just amazing. The donation we received from Nisa will provide  families with our fresh chicken dinner boxes, which is just amazing.The donations were made via Nisarsquos lsquoMaking a Dference Locallyrsquo charity which raises funds in-store from the sale of Co-op and Heritage own brand products and has seen the Pinkie Farm Convenience Store donate almost pound, to local causes.The donations are just one of many ways in which the store is reaching out to support the local community, having recently launched new pound lsquoessentials kitsrsquo aimed at helping the most vulnerable people in the community and those who are self-isolating.Food kits have also been given to staff at Musselburgh Primary Health Care Centre and fresh produce contributed to East Lothian Foodbank, amongst other initiatives to help those most in need.Thank you for reading this story. While I have your attention, I also have an important request to make.In order for us to continue to providetrusted local news, I am asking you to also please purchase a copy of our newspaperyou have notalready.Trusted news has never been so important -and neither has your support.The Courier is not immune to the severe pressures brought on businesses up and down the land by the Covid- lockdown.Soyou are able to buy a copy for yourself - and maybe even for a neighbour too who is not able to get to the shops - then we would be very grateful.Andyou do wish to support us, please check with your local newsagent to seethey can deliver the Courier to you.There is also an E-Edition that can be read on your PC, phone or tablet - just click the lsquoE-Editionrsquo tab under the Couriermasthead on the homepage of this website for more details.We want to be able to continue telling you all about our community heroes: our NHS staff, council staff, teachers, carers, shop owners and shop workers, posties and bus and train driversand the army of volunteers in every town and village helping the vulnerable.But we need your support to do so. If you can, please buy a paper. And keep safe and keep well.Thank you.Robbie Scott, Editor

title: delivering-hope-cheer-supplies-couriers-community
story: Couriers are being delivered to  North Berwick residents who are unable to leave their homes due to coronavirus shielding thanks to a new support fund to help people in the town.While in Haddington, the townrsquos Rotary Club this week purchased  copies to deliver to residents in lockdown in their town.North Berwick Community Council chairman Judy Lockhart said the initiative was aimed, primarily, at residents who did not have access to the internet but wanted to find out what was happening in the area and to get vital information about how to get help and support.Copies of the paper are delivered by North Berwick Community Emergency Resilience Group volunteers to housing for older people, care homes, the day centre and people who were not able to get out of their homes.ldquoWe want to ensure that everyone knows whatrsquos going on and how to get help and support at a very dficult time, said Judy.ldquoThe Courier is a leline. We know local newsagents deliver to many people, but this short-term scheme will ensure that people who donrsquot get a delivery or who canrsquot afford a Courier are kept in touch. It is also important to support the Courier during this periodwe are to see it survive. Newspapers are essential for local democracy and the Courier regularly reports on issues we discuss at the council.One of the volunteers who deliver the newspaper is Susan Taylor ndash in her beloved Dolly CV which goes by the name of Myrtille.Susan, whose day job is working for the Church of Scotland as an executive assistant, is one of the team of resilience group volunteers picking up prescriptions for residents.ldquoI volunteered because I really feel for those people in our community who are at risk and isolated due to the Covid- outbreak, she said. ldquoI have met some lovely people so far and am glad I am in a position to help.The project is paid for through the townrsquos Community Emergency Resilience Fund ndash which comprises public donations, funding from North Berwick Community Council and the North Berwick Trust.Rotary Haddington was always looking for ways to support its community, said club president Malcolm Collins.ldquoOur idea to bulk-buy and distribute copies of the Courier to the elderly and vulnerable originated from one of our members who was quick to realise that a signicant number of such people would soon begin to feel isolated and lose touch with what was happening locallythey were unable to get out and buy a copy, he added.ldquoAs well as providing local news, the initiative shown by the Courier by including pages of extra puzzles in the paper was also thought to be useful to help keep folk entertained during these dficult times.ldquoWe have now taken this idea forward and arranged to bulk-buy copies of the Courier each week in advance, have them delivered to a central hub and then arranged for them to be distributed to other locations where they can be made available to those in need e.g. Our Community Kitchen, those in care homes and other locations as they become known to us.Rotary Haddington members would ensure that the papers were delivered where they were needed, he added.Courier Editor Robbie Scott said: ldquoWersquore so grateful to these groups for supporting our communities during lockdown and the amazing work they do inspires us to produce the best papers that we can.ldquoFor them to also directly support us at a dficult time for all businesses is incredible and we thank them immensely.Anyone wishing to buy copies of the Courier for delivery to communities should email rscott@eastlothiancourier. Thanks to Alasdair Northrop for help in compiling this reportThank you for reading this story. While I have your attention, I also have an important request to make.In order for us to continue to providetrusted local news, I am asking you to also please purchase a copy of our newspaperyou have notalready.Trusted news has never been so important -and neither has your support.The Courier is not immune to the severe pressures brought on businesses up and down the land by the Covid- lockdown.Soyou are able to buy a copy for yourself - and maybe even for a neighbour too who is not able to get to the shops - then we would be very grateful.Andyou do wish to support us, please check with your local newsagent to seethey can deliver the Courier to you.There is also an E-Edition that can be read on your PC, phone or tablet - just click the lsquoE-Editionrsquo tab under the Couriermasthead on the homepage of this website for more details.We want to be able to continue telling you all about our community heroes: our NHS staff, council staff, teachers, carers, shop owners and shop workers, posties and bus and train driversand the army of volunteers in every town and village helping the vulnerable.But we need your support to do so. If you can, please buy a paper. And keep safe and keep well.Thank you.Robbie Scott, Editor

title: uk-lockdown-eased-schools-travel-sport
story: This will be a ldquomenu of options with the dates and times driven by the current state of the outbreak in the UK, he added.Ministers have faced continued questioning over the UKrsquos plan for lting its coronavirus lockdown, as European countries begin to ease their own restrictions.Italy and Spain are among those planning small steps to relax measures, while the Scottish and Welsh governments have set out dferent visions of how the current restrictions could be lted when the outbreak is under control.The next three-week review of the lockdown restrictions is due on Thursday, May .But how could the lockdown be lted across ious sectors  Heres a round-up of what you need to know.SchoolsUnder lockdown, schools and colleges have largely been closed, except for the children of essential workers, and it is thought this could be among the first restrictions to be eased.But Education Secretary Gavin Williamson previously said the Government had ldquono plans to open schools over the summer period, while Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said it would be ldquoinconceivable without some further measures in place.Head teachers have previously been advised to start making preparations on how schools could safely reopen, with the Association of School and College Leaderssuggesting a staggeredof pupils.ConstructionSome of Britainrsquos largest housebuilders ndash including Persimmon, Taylor Wimpey and Redrow ndash have already announced plans to reopen building sites in late April or early May.Under Government guidance, construction has been permittedin accordance with social distancing rules, but many companies halted work in response to the crisis.The Home Builders Federation said the restart is expected to be gradual, being dependent on how far supporting suppliers and services, such as building inspectors, mortgage lenders and conveyancers, can alsoto work.Activity will also be limited until the Government changes advice which effectively prohibits all but exceptional house moves.OfficesProperty services provider CBRE has drawn from its experiences in Asia to issue guidance to workplaces on how offices might approach re-opening in the future.It advises against a ldquofull throttleto work, with social-distancing measures needing to be reduced gradually and in line with public health guidance.It suggests businesses should establish internal taskforces to consider issues around access to PPE supplies, touchless technologies, temperature screening and reconfiguring work environments.Social gatheringsLimited social gatherings could be permitted in an easing of lockdown, but should be accompanied by extensive testing and contact tracing, one expert has suggested.Dr Joshua Moon, research fellow in sustainability research methods in the Science Policy Research Unitat the University of Sussex Business School, said the Government could adopt a ldquoslow release valve approach to the issue.He explained a phased approach might see certain sections of the population, for example healthy middle-aged people, given more freedoms initially, but he warned this risked the most vulnerable suffering the hardships of lockdown the longest.Dr Moon said family ldquoclusters could gradually be permitted to socialise, but could not make long journeys to do so, while most businesses remained shut.ldquoThe idea is that within those groups you can quite easily test, trace and isolate, he said, adding that it was harder to monitor for people moving around in public.HospitalitySector representative body UKHospitality has focused its energies on getting business support extended to places like bars and restaurants.A spokesman suggested that evenvenues were allowed to open with reduced capacity, businesses would still struggle financially.The All Party Parliamentary Group for Hospitality and Tourism has launched an urgent inquiry into how the sectors could reopen.This includes looking at operational challenges, reactivating supply chains, Government support and encouraging demand. A report is expected by mid-May.Pub chain Wetherspoonrsquos has said it plans to reopen its bars and hotels in June and said that due to it having larger than average pubs social distancing measures could be applied.RetailMinisters are thought to be considering allowing some non-essential businesses to open, such as garden centres and car showrooms, provided social-distancing could be maintained.Lobby group the British Retail Consortium has produced guidelines on how stores could prepare for the easing of restrictions.The guidance draws on lessons learned from supermarkets in recent weeks to ensure the re-opening of non-essential firms can be done safely.Advice coverslimiting entry and exit points, using floor markings to outline social distancing and keeping changing rooms closed.The guidance also suggests installing cleaning stations with hand sanitiser and disinfectant wipes at the front of stores.SportIt is understood Culture Secretary Olive Dowden has been working on a plan for major sports to be played behind closed doors when some social-distancing rules are eased.Weekly meetings are to be held between the Government, Public Health England and medical officials from sports bodies, with the issue due to be on the table when ministers review current measures next month.Key questions that need to be tackled include testing requirements, burdens on emergency services and the possible impact on fan behaviour ndash such as impromptu gatherings outside grounds.Sporting bodies are understood to be keen to resume full training safely as soon as possible.TravelLast week, low-cost European carrier Wizz Air announced plans to resume some flights from Luton Airport on May .Cabin crew will be required to wear masks and gloves on all flights and will distribute sanitising wipes for passengers, while new distancing measures will also be introduced during boarding.Mr Raab has indicated that officials are looking at possible checks at air and sea ports, with passengers arriving in the UK required to quarantine for  days.Meanwhile, the Rail, Maritime and Transportunion warned there was ldquozero chance of ramping up transport services soon, amid speculation of an increase on May  or May  when a new rail timetable is due.Last week, industry sources said no dates have yet been agreed or announced.

title: community-resilience-can-turn-help
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port SetonTHE resilience effort in Cockenzie and Port Seton has been helping launch a Fair Share hub at the Port Seton Centre this past week.The charity Fair Share delivers surplus food from supermarkets to the centre every Friday.The hub will cover the whole of East Lothian and support the centrersquos existing work to provide hot meals and food packs to families in need and children who would usually receive free school meals.Bryan Hickman, chairman of the local community council, which is leading the resilience effort, said: ldquoWe are still delivering food to those who need it but the Fair Share hub has been set up.ldquoWe receive food like coffee, cereal, milk and biscuits but this could change every week.ldquoItrsquos really good news that we have set this up as it will help us give other types of food. It will also help us financially because it is free.Meanwhile, the resilience effort is continuing to help those in need when requests come in, and currently has about  volunteers.A volunteer has also started offering a dog walking service.Contact detailsThose who require assistance can call the resilience emergency number on  . Updates are also posted on the Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council Twitter twitter CandPSCC and Facebook pages www.facebook Cockenzie-and-Port-Seton-Community-Council-.East SaltounHumbie, East and West Saltoun and BoltonFOUR volunteer groups are operating to help residents of neighbouring rural villages during the coronavirus pandemic.A resilience group, involving members of the Humbie, East and West Saltoun and Bolton Community Council, was previously formed.Alastair Beck, community council treasurer, said: ldquoVolunteers in the four village groups are supporting residents in their communities.ldquoAnyone in need of support, whether for shopping, pharmacy runs, etc, or who would just like someone to talk to should make contact with their village coordinator.Contact detailsPeople in Bolton should contact Shena Jamieson on   or by email shenajamieson@aol.East Saltoun residents can contact Buffy Neilson on   or buffyneilson@yahoo.In West Saltoun, Derek Smith is the point of contact on   or by emailing coruisk@gmail.Finally, in Humbie, people are encouraged to call Margo Hodge on   or email humbiehelp@gmailMacmerryMacmerry and GladsmuirA LEAFLET drop to all residents across Macmerry and Gladsmuir last week led to the numbers of calls dealt with by the resilience team double.The team also offer a hot food service, and requests for this have quadrupled in the past week from two to eight.Stevie Sutherland, one of the resilience co-ordinators, said: ldquoI definitely envisage this increasing as it develops.ldquoSome might use it for a couple of days, some might use it for a couple of months.ldquoMaybe we can give a bit more help, askingthere is anything  they need.ldquoNeighbours are also looking after one another and they seem to be managing themselves.ldquoI think most people receiving meals are over .ldquoAll that happens is they are getting one hot meal per day. They might not be getting anything  but itrsquos just making sure they are getting at least one every day.Children have also been receiving wool in craft packs and are encouraged to make colourful pom poms, and hang them from their gates or a nearby lamppost.Stevie said: ldquoThe pom poms will start gathering pace now. Wersquove also put some posts up about it on social media. ldquoHopefully we are going to be inundated with them.ldquoWe want both villages to be decorated with as much colour as possible, in support of frontline workers.Volunteers at the resilience group are continuing to help with prescription and shopping collections.Stevie added: ldquoItrsquos just about getting that help out there.Contact detailsMore information is available on the resilience grouprsquos Facebook and Twitter pages, at facebook groups   and twitter MacmerryTeamMusselburghMusselburghAN AVERAGE of  lunch packs have been prepared and distributed weekly, as well as a daily distribution of emergency food packs by the growing army of  volunteers who make up the Resilient Musselburgh team.And about  free soup and sandwich lunches have been distributed to Whitecraig residents each week, Monday to Friday, by Graham Blaikie, who runs Mercat Grill, helped by Mrs Bennett.The team is also now providing freshly cooked meals.Community Councillor Margaret Stewart explained: ldquoHickory Foods, based at Eskmills, have offered us their kitchen facilities and staff for free to prepare freshly cooked meals which are delivered into the community.ldquoThe staff at the base identy, from referral forms, those who they feel would be most in need and make contact to offer this food support.ldquoWe are trialling this on a two-week basis, where a three-course freshly prepared meal is delivered to those identied for seven days a week.ldquoThis week  meals will have been delivered. This support is specically targeted at vulnerable members of the community, where it is felt that they would benefit from a nutritious meal. All meals are packaged and labelled with instructions for heating.ldquoThis will be reviewed after the first two weeks. However, we have been seeking feedback and, so far, it has been exceptional, with many comments of appreciation and thanks.She added: ldquoWe are still looking to build on our pool of volunteers to ensure sustainability, so anyone who would be interested in supporting us can register via eastlothian.gov.uk info  musselburgh_area_partner ship  resilient_musselburgh.As well as the pound, awarded to the Musselburgh Area Partnership to support the whole community response, Resilient Musselburgh has received a number of funding donations from community groups and organisations.Volunteers have been delivering information leaflets to households in targeted areas and Councillor Andy Forrest arranged for Musselburgh Post Office to deliver leaflets to all other locations.Contact detailsThe Resilient Musselburgh dedicated support number is  .PrestonpansPrestonpansDEMAND for assistance from the Prestonpans resilience team increased last week, reflecting both the pressure families are under going into week five of the lockdown, and a wider awareness of the support available to local people.Allan Sneddon, who is leading the Prestonpans resilience effort, said: ldquoOur volunteers have started providing a dog walking service for several people who are shielding, and this is being co-ordinated on our team leadersrsquo WhatsApp group. This seems to be working very well.ldquoThe three local Scotmid stores in Prestonpans are offering a free home delivery service and, with the help of our resilience volunteersrsquo leaflets advertising the service, have been delivering throughout the town. We are also helping to deliver shopping orders.The Pantry, operating from the Pennypit, also saw demand for meals increase in week four, with  meals delivered to households throughout the town.The Pantry is receiving lots of practical support in the form of food donations from local stores in the area, and financial donations have been given by the Prestonpans and Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Councils, PSG Area Partnership, Prestonpans British Legion, Prestonpans Labour Club and Longniddry Villa FC.Prestonpans Community Council have also set aside funds to help households who are struggling to make ends meet and the Corra Foundation, Scottish Governmentrsquos Food Fund, the Prestonpans British Legion and RBL Scotland Pipe Band have made signicant donations to this fund.Contact detailsIf anyone needs help, they should telephone   or email prestonpansresilience@gmailIF YOUR resilience group would like to purchase copies of the Courier to deliver to residents who are shielding and unable to leave their homes then please email Courier Editor Robbie Scott via rscott@eastlothiancourier for details. Copies can be delivered to a destination of your choice before being distributed by your volunteers.

title: shop-visit-sting-tail-scorpion-discovered
story: Adrian Nowak, who lives in Musselburgh town centre, found a dead scorpion lying underneath the fruit while out for a recent shopping trip at the supermarket on Newhailes Road."I went to Lidl to get some essentials and I thought about getting melon and found it under one of the melons I picked up - it had been squashed," said Mr Nowak, a chef at a local care home, who bought the melon.A spokesperson for Lidl said: "At Lidl, we pride ourselves on having thorough procedures in place to ensure that our fresh fruit and vegetables are of the highest possible quality for our customers. We are, therefore, disappointed that these expected high standards have not been met on this occasion and would like to sincerely apologise to the customer."We can confirm that it has also been escalated to our Quality Assurance team to investigate further with the supplier."Mr Nowaks photos attracted a lot of interest on social media with one post staying: "I bet you social distanced yourself from that as quickly as possible!"Another read: "When was in Royal Navy we got our stores in foreign ports. Chef checks bananas before go in chilly room, us two stokers there to ensure fridges donrsquot keep tripping. Opens box and spider size of a hand on top unit was alive but, because of being in cool temperatures, it lay still well three guys trying to get up a vertical ladder wasnrsquot easy."One stated: "I was stung by one of them in Guatemala - not pleasant at all."Another said: "Well this story has a sting in the tail.""If you import food from foreign countries its to be expected there are always going to be a few extra guests along for the ride . . . just be alert and be on the lookout, its part of the deal," joked another.

title: skyes-limit-sabhal-mor-ostaig---unique-gaelic-only-college-set-stunning-island-location
story: Situated in the stunningly beautul peninsula of Sleat in the south end of the island, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is a unique Gaelic-only environment and the only college of its kind offering further and higher education through the medium of the language.The college offers a range of provision from beginnersrsquo courses to a PhD, with the flexibility of studying part-time or full-time, on campus or via distance learning. At a crucial time in the survival of the language, graduates have helped create a Gaelic speaking workforce that now holds key posts across a wide range of sectors in Scotland.Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is one of the key partners in fulfilling the governmentrsquos objectives in the National Gaelic Plan, which aims to increase the number of people speaking the language and accelerate the growth of Gaelic.Many people are keen to learn more about the language because of its rich culture and the college provides a wide range of short courses in Gaelic language, song and traditional music. Ceilidhs, workshops, conversation circles and music sessions all create an encouraging atmosphere that bring together students from  countries across five continents.As a modern, innovative college, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig has excellent learning resources on campus including an exceptional library collection, residential student accommodation, broadcast and recording facilities and a Gaelic medium childcare facility on site. It also has a growing international reputation for academic research.The college was founded on the principle of being part of the local and wider community and its activities are greatly enhanced by co-operative links, being home to a number of signicant national creative and cultural projects such as Tobar an Dualchais, Ainmean Agraveite na h-Alba and Cagravenan Graphics Studio. It plays a leading role in the promotion of the Gaelic arts and culture and also offers an international exchange programme with universities in Canada and Ireland.The collegersquos graduates include Seumas Greumach , Chief Executive of An Comunn Gaidhealach, which runs the Royal National Mod, who studied the Cugraversa Comais in  and then ed for another year to study Cagravenan is Cultar na Gagraveidhlig. He went to Sabhal Mograver to improve his language skills and says he would not hold his present job had he not become a fluent speaker.ldquoI was fully immersed in the language at Sabhal Mograver Ostaig, which is essential to become fluent in any language. he says. ldquoYou could hear Gaelic being spoken every day, in every situation and that helped me no end in improving my own Gaelic. I gained a great deal of confidence in terms of Gaelic grammar, spelling and writing, all of which has been invaluable in my working le.BBC weather presenter, Joy Dunlop, is another graduate of the college who says the fluency in Gaelic she developed at the college has given her many opportunities that she otherwise would not have had.She studied Gaelic as a second language when she was a pupil at Oban High School then decided to do her sixth year at the college. She initially planned to stay for just one year to do the Cugraversa Comais but loved it so much she stayed for four, graduating with a BAin Cagravenan agus Cultar na Gagraveidhlig .ldquoAttending Sabhal Mograver was a revelation for me, she says. ldquoThe education I received was unparalleled.ldquoThe personal support and guidance I received from all the staff was of the highest level and I always felt that our teachers were genuinely invested in both the language itself and our progress.ldquoBeing immersed in the language is definitely the best way to learn, dficult as it could be at times, and having the opportunity to speak Gaelic in both the classes and the community was a real help to me.ldquoSimply,you genuinely want to learn Gaelic, there is no better place to do so than Sabhal Mograver Ostaig. Tha i math agus tha i math dhut!

title: vicky-allan-feeling-burnt-home-school-home-work
story: def. exhausted or in poor health due to overworkThere have been many times over the past few weeks when itrsquos seemed to me that the much-talked of coronavirus slowness was a myth, or something Irsquod failed, personally, to grasp. At first I thought I was the only person feeling this, but then I started to realise many others were too. People I come in contact with kept telling me they felt more busy, not less ndash and Irsquom not just talking about key workers, but a wide demographic in terms of income and occupation. These people, of course, were mostly not those who had been furloughed or lost work. They were also, mostly, people who had kids.Last week, this paper reported that millions of people forced to work from home ldquomay be at risk of burnout as their work-le balance is turned upside down. It may seem hyperbolic for us to talk about feeling burnt out by just the mere challenge of trying to work and home-school our children, but therersquos a pace of le for many of us here thatrsquos undoubtedly unsustainable. Irsquom waking at am to get time to work before home school starts, and Irsquove talked to many others stretching out their days, doing their double shts.We may be moving around less, but many of us are as busy. When our cars, trains, planes and workplaces stopped, tech rushed in ndash Zoom, Microsoft Teams, streamed talks and events ndash and not just for us, but also for our children. On Facebook this week I found myself joining in on a thread, started by a parent with a small business, who complained that she was struggling to get to grips with the confusing system of online school assignments being sent out to her kids.It echoed my own feelings that one of the biggest challenges of the recent weeks had been to try to work out what my eldest son, at secondary school, is expected to do. He wants to manage it himself, but it seems unmanageable. Work arrives on dferent s ndash via email, Teams, website downloads ndash with assignments often not where you expect them to be.Reports into lockdown delivery of online education are revealing a staggering dference between inidual schools, and crucially between the state and private sector. Neil Mackay, writing in this paper last week, reported that a survey by the Scottish Secondary Teachersrsquo Association before Easter found that less than half of children were engaging with teachers. He described how one teacher had told him she only had four children out of  join an online lesson. I recognise that. My son was one of three in such a low turn-out class and only because we happened to spot the message when it came in.And I understand why kids arenrsquot engaging. It feels to me asour childrenare being thrown in at the deep end and the swimming skills they have to learn are a form of digital self-management. Some may emerge at the end having learned practices of self-organisation, but many will not. Some, in some houses, have no access to digital learning at all. Irsquom not blaming the inidual teachers, many of whom are locked in a struggle of trying to deliver learning through new technology s, while also possibly juggling their own kids. I also think itrsquos wrong to blame parents. The wider system itself should deliver a lot better for all kids.I also, however, think that children are part of a wider world, and above all we need to be working out right now how to make this better for all of us in the new normal.The truth is Irsquom someone who believes in slowness. I take on board Danny Dorlingrsquos argument that evidence shows we are already going through a period of technological slowdown, economic deceleration and declining growth.But it feels aseven in this pause, le for many of us is only getting more digitally hectic. We could resist that ndash let our kids get bored and drop out at work ndash but most of us are still struggling to earn and the answers to many of our current problems demand work. They also require rethinking whatrsquos important ndash and, what with home school and homework, many of us are too busy for that.Feeling wakeful  The Covid pandemic, a recipe for insomniaVicky Allan is feeling grateful. How coronavirus is showing us a new gratitude

title: issue-day-old-albums-offer-lockdown-comfort
story: Nostalgia Itrsquos absolutely at play, with a wistful yearning for the reassurance of days gone by evidently influencing our listening choices as new figures show a surge in the purchasing of old albums and also the streaming of songs from the s, s, s and s.New music isnrsquot getting a look in A glance at the recent iTunes Storersquos album charts will be a trip down memory lane, with Mariah Careyrsquos  album, EMC number one in late April, with other albums currently in the top  in the UK including Madonnarsquos Immaculate Collection, which was released  years ago, as well as greatest hits offerings from Simply Red, Abba, The Carpenters and Rod Stewart.Other favourites The Ultimate Bee Gees from  is rising up the album charts, along with old Prince, Guns NrsquoRoses, R.E.M. and Fleetwood Mac albums.The most streamed Elvisrsquos ldquoJailhouse Rock" is a s classic being ed to, along with Johnny Cashrsquos ldquoI Walk the Line. ldquoAt Last by Etta James is a s favourite, along with The Beatlesrsquo ldquoHere Comes the Sun, while Bill Withers - who passed away just last month - was among the most listened to artists fromthe s, with ldquoAint No Sunshine all according to data from streaming giant, Spoty.The s A-has "Take on Me" and Cyndi Laupers "Girls Just Want to Have Fun" are the s hits being ed to on streaming, with Ms Lauper pointing to the role of nostalgia, saying itrsquos the same for her too at the moment as "Music marks time for me, so when I hear a song, it brings me back to that exact moment in time.Playlists Spotys "All Out s" playlist has more than . million followers and since lockdown began across much of the world, with more people based at home, there has been a % increase in listeners making nostalgic-themed playlists.We are all listening to more music generally Again, amid lockdown, smart speaker listening has jumped by %, according to eMarketer, as we call on digital assistants like Alexa and Siri to play music that when first released, would either have boomed out of hi-fis, boomboxes or record players.A link to the past Behavioural science writer, David DiSalvo, said the world is finding in music, a connection to stability of old. He said: ldquoNostalgia is an extremely powerful force linked to memory, but it has a way of putting a rosier view on our memory. When we smell those chocolate chip cookies, itrsquos a link to memory that brings us back to a more stable, comfortable place in our lives. We can inhabit it in our minds and feel a level of support that most of us arenrsquot feeling right now because there is so much instability.

title: letters-withholding-council-cash-causing-real-hardship
story: What is absolutely clear is that councils are in the red as never before. The Scottish Government has a deplorable track record in trousering the local government funding it gets from Westminster for its own ends. Over the last  years, Scottish councils have lost seven per cent of their funding despite rising demand. As a result they have drained their reserves, and now find themselves in a nightmarish situation where revenue is noseing with people defaulting on rent and Council Tax just as demand for their services is hitting an all-time high. Unlike charities and businesses, councils cannot furlough their staff but have to bear all the costs of the lockdown themselves.All this means that the people councils serve are not only facing more hardship than ever before but far more than they need to. We see that, for example, in the thousands of businesses who have yet to receive their emergency grants, or the countless children who lack the support and equipment to be able to benefit from home schooling.Councils are the frontline when it comes to helping people through this crisis, and deserve much better treatment from this niggardly Government.Linda Holt , Anstruther.I THINK that Kate Forbes is right to seek proper detailed analyses of local government financial issues before releasing emergency funding. A fund of pound million will not go far.Already you note that Edinburgh and Highland are ldquoclaiming poundmillion between them.I realise that local authorities are doing a good job in these strange times but there are many things that are budgeted for that they are not doing too. I donrsquot think we should reimburse councils for lost income like lower parking charges or leisure centre fees .Letrsquos see the accounts.Allan McDougall, Neilston.THEATRES and concert halls were amongst the first public buildings to close to the public when the lockdown was introduced and we expect to be amongst the last to re-open. Every indication of a timetable for ato a ldquonew normalcy is that we will most likely find ourselves at the end of the phased process and it is equally likely that a large number valued cultural institutions will be have been lost along the way.It is a devastating situation for so many providers of cultural activity in Scotland. However, we have no choice but to accept this situation and we wait to be told under what conditions we may be able to open again so that we can plan to provide performances and events in restricted conditions. Many theatres like the Tron have performances ready to stage this autumn while at the same time we are well aware that the delay to re-opening may be a lot longer.I assume this principle will apply to all such places of public gathering. However, I read today that the Catholic Church in Scotland is drawing up a strategy to re-open buildings and for masses toin the near future . I wish the church good luck in its discussions with the Scottish Government on this issue but I am confused by the rationale. We are all buildings where the public assembles to communally participate in events. If a special dispensation is given then we should be allowed to stage theatre shows in churches after mass has ended ... at least until our own buildings can open again.Andy Arnold, Artistic Director, Tron Theatre, Glasgow.I AM a   live-in carer dedicated to caring for elderly and disabled people.I am employed by an agency currently advertising on national television for staffThis week I phoned the office three times to ask for PPE to be delivered to the address where I am looking after a client with underlying health issues. On the third call I was told to come to the office to collect the itemsMy client and I are in isolation, as advised by the Government, with essential items delivered to the door.Apart from the danger of leaving the house, getting to the companyrsquos office would involve several public transport journeys with the inherent risk of contracting the virus.Your front page today highlights the poor pay and dficulties faced by carers such as myself .It is most discouraging to be so undervalued by ones employer, nevertheless, I am taking the appropriate measures to protect my client and myself.Name and address supplied.Read more: Councils told to use reserves as poundm support withheld

title: Opinion  Marianne Taylor  Drop the jingoism  Boris  VE Day is about more than flags and bunting
story: Certainly not when tens of thousands of people in the UK have died of Covid-, thousands more will die in the months to come, and our doctors, nurses and carers still donrsquot have the protective equipment they need to do their jobs. All our lives have been changed beyond recognition by coronavirus and we have no idea when, or , they will everto normal.This is a time for sober reflection. And serious consideration of how, as iniduals and a society, we will recover from the psychological, social and economic effects of this crisis.And yet Boris Johnson wants to focus on bunting, street parties and how ldquogreat Britain is as we mark the th anniversary of VE Day on Friday. Not even a brush with death and stay in intensive care, it seems, can cure the Prime Minister of crass attempts to distract us from how poorly he and his Government has handled things.But what really galls me about Mr Johnsonrsquos jingoism is how it overshadows and insults valuable lessons from the end of the Second World War, not least around how to rebuild shattered lives and countries following unimaginable loss and trauma. That is, after all, what the war generation largely succeeded in doing across western Europe after Germany was finally liberated from the tyranny of Nazism in May .With few members of this extraordinary generation left ndash and the virus having a devastating impact on those that remain ndash opportunities to listen to their thoughts and experiences firsthand are running out. It is particularly cruel that so many of those still with us are currently having to be shielded away from families and friends. I trust technology will help us hear their voices this week.The timing of this anniversary, in the midst of a global pandemic, gives people of every age a unique opportunity to reconnect with the war generation at a deeper level. From  to  lives were changed and lost abruptly, hopes and dreams shattered. Unexpected opportunities arose and dferent paths had to be taken. People, communities and entire spheres of le were forced to re-evaluate what mattered. Certainties, priorities and value systems changed. We are going through some of these things now, albeit in a dferent way. But I donrsquot doubt the experiences of  years ago can give us strength and solace in the dficult months and years to come.Though all my grandparents have been dead for many years, I am lucky enough to have treasured wartime photographs, letters, medals and memorabilia. On May  I will be thinking particularly of my two grandmothers, one a young mother whose wounded RAF gunner husband had just ed home after six years away, the other a munitions worker in a strange city celebrating her rd birthday alone. Both struggled in the aftermath of war to find connection and fulfilment, but succeeded in raising loving families. Both were and remain much-loved.I will also be thinking of the Scottish soldiers still fighting their way across Europe until the very end of the war, as well as those who stayed on to build the peace. I will think, too, of the Germans, freed on May  from Nazism but destined to be ided until . My American husbandrsquos relatives, who in May  were still fighting in Asia ndash and would continue to do so well into the next generation ndash will also be on my mind.As the poignant footage of VE Day shows, the end of war was celebrated with tears of joy and relief, passionate kisses, warm embraces and dancing in fountains. But, as my own family recounted to me firsthand, it was also tinged with loss, sadness, trauma and fear for the future. Some did meet again, many, of course, did not.This extraordinary generation rebuilt the country in the aftermath, creating many of the institutions we value most today, not least the NHS. And, as -year-old Captain Tom Moorersquos astonishing fundraising efforts highlight, they keep contributing in the most inspiring ways.We donrsquot need bunting or a commemorative coin to celebrate VE Day, Winston Churchillrsquos victory speech on the telly or Joan Collins wrapped in a union flag . And we certainly donrsquot need Boris Johnson insulting our intelligence with a jingoistic reframing of the past when he should be concentrating on the present.If we choose to look beyond flag-waving, history, as ever, has much to teach us. I for one am willing to learn.Allcolumnistsare free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: derek-mackay-can-pick-golden-goodbye-12-000-week
story: Mr Mackay stood down as a minister in early February after it emerged he had bombarded a -year-old boy with messages, but remains anMSP.He is automatically entitled to a severance payment of pound, ndash the equivalent of three monthsrsquo Cabinet salary ndash for losing ministerial office.:The messages that led to Derek Mackays downfallThis sum is paid out by the Scottish Parliament after  days, which will be this week.A Holyrood spokesman said: ldquoLegislation states that, after a -day period, the equivalent of three monthsrsquo salary is payable on ceasing to holda ministerial position. That equatesto pound,.ldquoThe Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Bodyhas no discretion in relation to the making of payments.ldquoThe act says the SPCB must pay the grant after  days. It is a matter for the member thereafter.Mr Mackay did not respond to an email askinghe intended to accept the payment, or give it to charity.He has now earned more than pound, as the MSP forRenfrewshire North and West since disappearing from public view in early February.There is no mechanism to remove him from Holyrood, and he remains entitled to his pound, salary as an MSP.If he continues as an MSP until the next Holyrood elections, he willalso be entitled to around pound, asa ldquoresettlement grant.A Scottish Conservative spokesman said: ldquoGiven the circumstances of his resignation, itrsquos pretty outrageous Derek Mackay is due a ministerial payout.: Fresh calls for Derek Mackay to quit as he earns almost pound, since scandalldquoMore to the point, no one has seen or heard from Mr Mackay since he was forced to quit.ldquoTaxpayers not only deserve morein terms of representation for his constituents, they deserve some answers from the man himself.Mr Mackay, , contacted the schoolboy on social media last August without knowing his age, then sent him persistent messages over six months.He called the teenager ldquocute, invited him to dinner and asked that their conversations be kept secret.Mr Mackayrsquos behaviour came to light after the messages were published in the Scottish Sun just hours before he was due to deliver Scotlandrsquos pound billion Draft Budget.Public Finance Minister Kate Forbes, who is now Finance Secretary, had to outline the tax and spending plans in his place.Opposition parties called Mr Mackayrsquos conduct ldquopredatory and suggested it amountedto grooming. However, police previously confirmed he will not face criminal charges, adding ldquothere is nothing to suggest an offence hasbeen committed.The SNP, which has suspended him from the party and removed the party whip at Holyrood, is holding its own internal inquiry into his conduct.The party did not respond when asked for an update on this investigation, orit has been in contact with Mr Mackay. It previously said he is ldquoreceiving appropriate medical treatment.In March, it was reported that some within the SNP were discussing the possibility Mr Mackay could retire due to ldquoill health.This would see him entitled to a severance payment equivalent to the pound, resettlement grant.The Herald previously reported the former ministerrsquos official website has been taken down.Archives show derekmackaymsp.org, which updated constituents on his activities and provided contact details, was still online as recently as March .In a statement released on the morning of February , Mr Mackay said he took ldquofull responsibility for his actions.ldquoI have behaved foolishly and I am truly sorry, he said. ldquoI apologise unreservedly to the inidual involved and his family.He added: ldquoServing in government has been a huge privilege and I am sorry to have let colleagues and supporters down.Mr Mackay was elected to Renfrewshire Council in  at the age of , became an MSP in  and rose to the position of finance secretary in May .He was previously seen as a rising star in the SNP and was talked of as a possible successor to Nicola Sturgeon.
